Comments: \t\t\t\t
THE SHELL AND BOTTOM HEAD HAVE PITTING AND GENERAL CORROSION THAT IS BELOW THE T MIN FOR THE DESIGN PRESSURE OF THIS VESSEL AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO KEEP THE VESSEL IN SERVICE A NEW T MIN FOR THE SHELL AND HEADS CAN BE ASSUMED. THE DEEPEST PITS COULD BE REPAIRED AND THE SHELL T MIN SET AT 0.400É?ù AND THE BOTTOM HEAD T MIN SET AT 0.640É?ù WHICH WOULD GIVE A SLIGHT AMOUNT OF CORROSION ALLOWANCE. AT THESE NEW VALUES THE VESSEL COULD BE OPERATED AT 92 PSI MAWP. THIS WOULD BE AT THE OWNERS DISCRETION. IT APPEARS THAT THE PRV ON THIS VESSEL IS SET AT 50 PSI.
FOR FULL CODE COMPLIANCE THE VESSEL SHALL BE DE-RATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE CALIFORNIA OCCUPOATIONAL SAFETY - PRESSURE VESSEL UNIT CIRCULAR LETTER PV-2006-2 AND CIRCULAR LETTER PV-2001-1.\t\t\t\t
\t\t\t\t
OUT OF SERVICE, TYE HAMMOND, 10/05/2009\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
UltraPipe Unit ID PAN FEE
UltraPipe Circuit 7886

Find in Virtual Tour
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD established procedures. 3 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 07/30/2019. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 07/30/2033 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 07/30/2014.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in fair condition. This piping circuit externally is insulated. The insulation is found to be in poor condition, with missing or damage insulation, and in the areas the insulation is missing the surface condition of the piping is covered with light to moderate surface rust. The piping supports surface was covered with light to moderate surface rust and no corrosion was present. Support hangers were found to be in fair condition. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 5 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 2 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Recommendations: Repair insulation as needed.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID ETHEL_D
UltraPipe Circut ID WELL 79

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the heads, shell, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the next inspection will be 06/07/2017. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 09/05/2019 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 6 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 03/11/2015. Caution TMLs are due to high corrosion rates.
API 510 External Inspection:
External visual inspection was performed and found this vessel to be in fair condition. The coating on this vessels exterior shell and heads is in fair condition. This vessel is supported by four legs welded to this vessel and found to be structurally sound. All anchors bolts were securely fastened to the concrete foundation. The concrete foundation is above grade level and in good condition with no spalling or cracking noted. There is one PSV located on this vessel and it is on the top head. This PSV is missing service tag. The manufacturer data plate pressure is set at 600 PSIG which is above the vessel MAWP of 225 PSI. Recommend replacing the PSV with the correct set pressure for this vessel. During the thickness measurement inspection on the 24É??É?? man way there is sign of internal wall loss recommend an internal inspection on the next available time. All bolted flange and threaded connections to the shell and heads. There is no visual evidence of leakage or corrosion found. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shut-down.
UltraPipe Unit ID ETHEL_D
UltraPipe Circut ID HEADER 4 TANK

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the heads, shell, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the next inspection will be 04/07/2017. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 01/06/2020 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There is 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 07/10/2014.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. The coating on vessels exterior shell is in fair condition. This vessel is supported by four legs and structurally sounds. All anchors bolts were found securely fastened to the concrete foundation. The concrete foundation is above grade level and in good condition with no spalling or cracking present. There is only one PSV located on this vessel and it is located on the top head. The PSV pressure is set at 225 PSIG. All bolted flange and threaded connections to the shell and heads, there is no visual evidence of leakage or corrosion found. The next internal inspection will be time based per API 510 at 5 years.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection.
UltraPipe Unit ID ETHEL_D
UltraPipe Circut ID HEADER 6 TANK

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD established procedures. 4 Thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 01/16/2018. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 09/25/2020 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 05/08/2015.
API 570 Visual Inspection :
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in fair condition. This piping circuit externally is insulated. The insulation is found to be in fair condition. The piping supports were covered with light to moderate surface rust with no corrosion present. Support hangers were found to be in fair condition. Dead weeds were found growing around the piping. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 10 year thickness and visual inspection interval per API (class 3 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Recommendations: Remove dead weeds to reduce fire hazard.
The next visual inspection will be 01/16/2018 due to low remaining life.
UltraPipe Unit ID ETHEL_D
UltraPipe Circut ID WELL 512

The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 10/14/2016 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There is 5 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 07/02/2015.
API 510 External Inspection:
The external condition of the vessel was found to be good for continued service with only minor issues noted at this time. The north and south foundation pedestals were found to be structurally sound and free from any significant spalling or cracks. The pedestal were not coating and the grouting around the saddle support base plates were found to have areas where grouting was broken and or missing. Saddle supports were in good condition but were found to have light rust and surface scale present at base plates where grouting was missing. All anchor bolts were secure and in good condition. Minor rust was noted at bolt threads. Both ends were double nutted and slotted with clearance to allow for expansion. This vessel‚Äôs exterior shell and heads are fully insulated and found to be in good condition. A visual external inspection could not be performed on the shell and heads exterior surface at this time do to the vessel being insulated. Note this vessel is missing a manufacturer‚Äôs date plate and some information was obtained from the U1A supplied from the customer on this vessel. All nozzles and attached piping appears to be in good condition. There is one PSV protecting this vessel and it is located on top of this vessel and set at 65 PSI. There are no signs of past or present leakage noted. The pressure and temperature gauges were found to be intact and legible with no indications of past or present leakage. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection.
UltraPipe Unit ID ETHEL_D
UltraPipe Circut ID V-220

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD established procedures. 4 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 07/22/2019. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 10/21/2025 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 07/22/2014.
API 570 Visual Inspection
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in fair condition. This piping circuit externally is insulated. The insulation is found to be in poor condition, with missing or damage insulation, and in the areas the insulation is missing the surface condition of the piping is covered with light to moderate surface rust. The piping supports surface was covered with light to moderate surface rust and no corrosion was present. Support hangers were found missing or damage in five locations on this piping circuit and in some the areas piping is sagging. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 5 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 2 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Recommendations: Repair insulation and support hangers as needed.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID ETHEL_D
UltraPipe Circut ID WELL 2-6

Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the heads, shell, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the next inspection will be 07/16/2016. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 08/01/2016 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 2 caution tml locations per the current thickness survey taken 06/30/2016 due to being close to the Tmin.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. The coating on the vessels exterior shell has some scrapes and chipped paint and is in fair condition. The original manufactures data plate is not attached to the vessel and is missing. All of the welds appear to be sound and in good condition. No bulges or deformations were found. The attached piping was in good condition and properly supported. No leaks were found on any of the flanges, piping, or vessel. This vessel is supported by 4 legs welded to a steel skid and the supports were in poor condition with two cracks found, one on the south west leg and the other on the northeast leg. The next external inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next scheduled shutdown.
UltraPipe Unit ID POSO
UltraPipe Circuit ID SAC-300A

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 02/23/2017. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 01/02/2018 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate and calculated corrosion rates. There are 1 caution TMLs at this time due to high corrosion rates.
API 510 External Inspection:
The external condition of the vessel was found to be good for continued service with only minor issues noted at this time. The vessel‚Äôs external paint condition was found to be serviceable with small localized areas of rust stain and chipped paint. The east side shell and top head had a large area of shallow external pitting. This vessel is missing the manufacturer data plate and no information on this vessel at time of this inspection. The vessel was altered by HDB and a repair plate was attached with design pressure of 100PSI @ 200¬∞F. All weld seams appeared to be sound and full profile with no evidence of any type of distortion or bulging found at any of the vessel‚Äôs head or shell surfaces. Attached piping appeared to be properly supported and no leaks or stains were noted at any of the nozzle locations. All connected piping appeared to be properly supported. This vessel is supported by four legs welded to the vessel and steel skid for a foundation and free of any visible cracking or corrosion. There are no ladders or platforms associated with this vessel. No grounding was found and should be attached to this vessel.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection. Internal inspection is highly recommended at the next planned shutdown due to high internal corrosion rates.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the heads, shell, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the next inspection will be 11/19/2016. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 01/08/2018 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution tml locations per the current thickness survey taken 10/02/2015. The next thickness survey will be half-life based due to low remaining life.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in fair condition. The paint coating on the vessels exterior shell is in fair-to-poor condition with an area on the south-west side that has coating failure and surface rusting present. The cause appears to be from a past leak at nozzle N-5.
The vessel is supported by 4 ‚ÄúI‚Äù beam style legs welded to the shell and bottom head. The legs are welded to a steel skid foundation which is sitting on a concrete pad. The concrete pad, steel skid, and supports are all in good condition. There is some sediment buildup in the foundation area directly under the vessel. The vessel shell and heads are in good condition with no dents, bulges or other deformations noted. The nozzles are in good condition but nozzle N-5 has some scale buildup on the top side that was not able to be removed.
The PSV is attached to nozzle N-7 on the top head and is set at 100PSI. The PSV was last serviced 06/23/2015.
The next visual inspection will be due on 11/19/2016 and is half-life based due to low remaining life.
Recommendations:
Touch up areas of coating failure or consider recoating the vessel.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shut-down.

API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found this vessel to be in good condition. The insulation on this vessels exterior shell and head number one is in fair condition. Head number two on the north end of this vessel is painted and in poor condition. This head is covered with moderate surface rust. No external corrosion are pitting was found. Noted external shell could not be inspected do to vessel being insulated at time of inspection. All nozzles and threaded connection to shell and heads have no evidence of leakage. All bolted flanges were free of any corrosion are pitting. This vessel is mounted on two concrete pillars the south end pillar is found to have spalling and the concrete is chipping off in area. North concrete pillar is in good condition. All anchors bolts were securely fastened to the concrete foundation and free of any rust scale or corrosion. The vertical ladder on the side of the vessel was structurally sound. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
Recommendations: Repair spalling on south end concrete pillar. Recoat north head and re torque bolting on the fire tube flanges.
A PI 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were not performed during this inspection.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection was not completed during this inspection.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
This vessel was taken out of service and pressure washed before internal inspection was performed on all accessible areas. The North and South head was found to be coated with a hard black product scale build-up scattered throughout the heads. On the North head some isolated pitting and corroded areas were found. The corroded and pitted areas varied in size and depth. A pit gauge was used to measure the depth of the corroded and pitted areas on the North head. The areas range from .060‚Äô‚Äô to .260‚Äô‚Äôdeep. Three locations were found to be corroded in excess of the corrosion allowance. The heads Nominal Thickness is .416‚Äô‚Äô and T-min for the heads is .238‚Äù @ 59 PSI. Those areas found for repair were marked up. See photos on page 10. Shell courses were coated with a hard black product scale buildup in various areas scattered throughout shell and in some areas where the scale was missing light surface rust was present. Some measurable pitting or corrosion was found. Isolated pitting and corroded areas were found scattered throughout the bottom of the shell. The corroded and pitted areas varied in size and depth. A pit gauge was used to measure the depth of the corroded and isolated areas on this vessel. The areas range from .010‚Äô‚Äô to .060‚Äô‚Äôdeep. An area on the south end next to a 4‚Äù nozzle has corrosion up to .200‚Äô‚Äô deep. See photo on page 11 for location. Nominal Thickness is .560‚Äù and T-min for the shell is .477‚Äù @ 59 PSI. One 4‚Äù nozzle on the North end and one 4‚Äù nozzle on the South end will require repair.
Recommendations: Repair areas that do not meet the acceptance criteria. After weld overlays; perform magnetic particle inspection on repairs as required. If flush patches are used then perform x-ray on the full penetration welds. Consider coating vessel internally before placing into service to prevent any further corrosion.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Update report: 8/11/2016.
Internal visual re-inspection was completed as requested by the customer on the areas that were repaired by Total Western. A total of 8 locations were repaired by weld over lay, Applus RTD performed magnetic particle testing on the repaired locations areas and found to be acceptable.

Comments:
OUT OF SERVICE PER STEVE PETERSON - 02/2015
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be time based at 5 years. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 02/12/2027 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate.
Recommended Inspection Date is 11/04/2014. There are 0 caution tmls per the current thickness reading taken 11/04/2009.
API 510 External Inspection: 11/04/2009 :
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. There is no insulation on the vessels exterior shell is in good condition. For full inspection data see inspection check list on pages 4 and 5 in this report. See photos below for visual info.
API 510 Internal Inspection: 03/22/2011 :
Based on Spot UT and VT performed, the vessel is good for use at the Design MAWP of 125 psi at 190 ?¯F Temperature.
There were no significant findings during the time of Internal inspection. The vessel was about ?? of filter media which gave limited access to the vessel and only the vacant portion was reviewed. There was product that coated the vessel and subsequently a clear view of the material could not be made.
The vessel had an internal rubber lining which has failed. It has begun to come apart from the vessel wall, and has major damage.
External UT was also performed on the top head where the previous area of concern was. There was no major pitting found and appeared to be mostly general corrosion.
After further review of the vessel manufacturerÉ??s U-1A, it was found that spot radiography was performed on the vessel and that the efficiency which was originally entered in as .85 for the heads could be raised to 1 per ASME SEC. VIII which would lower the Tmin. This was done and the vessel Tmin was re-calculated extending the next inspection date.
Berry Petroleum engineering will need to evaluate the findings of the TML readings, non-conformance issues É?? Applus RTD can assist with this data review. Continued monitoring of caution TMLs is recommended as part of the repair/replace decision process.
Subsequent inspection should be performed, within the requirements of API-510 so that long term and short term
corrosion rates can be calculated and compared.

Comments: \t\t\t\t
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the heads, shell, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the next inspection will be 05/11/2017. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 08/03/2037 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 0.1 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 05/11/2016. 1 reading was found below t-min at Course 2 270¬∞. Linear averaging was performed. The maximum 32‚Äù length was averaged with readings taken at 1‚Äù increments. The average thickness across this area is .629‚Äù. The average thickness was substituted for the actual thickness taken at this point. Subsequent thickness inspections should include the same linear averaging for this location. Linear averaging was performed in accordance with API-510 8th Edition 2003 addenda.\t\t\t\t
\t\t\t\t
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. The coating on this vessels exterior shell and heads was found to be in good condition, with no visible evidence of external corrosion found. This vessel is supported by two saddles and concrete pillars above grade level for a foundation. Anchor bolts are installed in each of the concrete pillars. The concrete pillars are not coated or fireproofed and found to be in fair condition with no spalling or any other significant problems present. The anchor bolting was found to be in satisfactory condition. The nozzles are welded couplings with small bore threaded connections. There are four pressure relief valves protecting this vessel. They are located on the top of this vessel and are set at 265 PSI. The PRV was installed in March 2015 new by Solar Turbines. There are no signs of past or present leakage noted. All external appurtenances including float, pressure and temperature gauges were good and appeared to be working properly. A grounding connection was located on the West end next to saddle support and was found to be in good condition. There are no ladders or platforms associated with this vessel. The next external inspection will be one year from the inspection taken on 5/11/2016 per customer‚Äôs request.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection.\t\t\t

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell, floor, and nozzles. Shell and nozzle readings were acceptable. 2/3rds of the floor TMLs were found to be below t-min of .100É?ù.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The foundation is in poor condition with heavy oil and soil buildups within the rock bed preventing adequate drainage. 3 cavities were found in the foundation extending under the tank located at plates P2, P11 and P13/14 Joint area. Discarded bolting and other miscellaneous debris was found within the rock bed. The tank is grounded through a connection at the course 1 P11/12 Plate joint
The tank shell was in fair condition with no signs of bulging or other deformations in the shell. All plate joint gaskets were found to be dry and brittle but no joint leaks were found at this time. 4 plate joints were found to have bolting with oil seepage at plate joint P12/13 in the first course and plate joints P1/2, P5/6, and P12/13 in the second course. Sample station piping was found leaking near the connection to the shell in the second course. A possible roof joint leak was found at shell course 2 plate 9. The roof was not accessible for up close inspection to determine if the leak was from the joint or run-off from the roof. The autogauge appears to be disconnected and out of service at this time.
Recommendations: Remove oil and soil buildup from the foundation. Restore foundation with clean rock and fill in cavities under the floor. Replace bolting with seepage. Monitor tank for plate joint gasket leaks. Remove autogauge if it will not be placed back into service. Repair leaking sample piping.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found the tank to be in very poor condition. Over 70 holes were found in the floor which appear to be caused by bottom side corrosion. 3 out of 14 floor plates did not have visible holes but thickness measurements on these plates is below t-min of .100É?ù. Several joints throughout the floor have bolting that is corroded or missing.
The tank shell is in good condition. The first course was covered in oil sludge. The sludge was scraped away in random locations which revealed a hard scale deposit which first appeared to be pitting in the shell. Once the scale deposit was removed, minor pitting was present less that .010É?ù. The second course appears to be in good condition but is not accessible for up close inspection at this time. Some shell bolting braces are corroded in the lower 12É?ù near the floor.
The tank roof is in very poor condition. 12 holes were found in the roof plates and several areas were visibly corroded. Heavy corrosion is visible in the roof support rafters, some rafters are almost completely corroded through. The center roof manway attachment to the roof is almost completely corroded.
Recommendations: Replace the roof and floor. Replace shell bolting braces. Completely clean and recoat tank.
Magnetic Flux Leakage Inspection:
Due to numerous holes found, magnetic flux leakage inspection was not completed at this time.

External inspection found the vessel to be in fair condition. The coating on this vessels exterior shell and heads are in fair condition, with no visible evidence of external corrosion found. This vessel is supported by two concrete pillars for a foundation and the anchor bolts are installed in each concrete pillars. Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell, floor and nozzles. All readings were found to be acceptable at this time.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The foundation is in poor condition with heavy oil and soil buildups within the rock bed preventing adequate drainage. 1 cavity was found in the foundation extending under the tank located at plates P9 & 10. Discarded bolting and other miscellaneous debris was found within the rock bed. The tank is grounded through a connection at the course 1 P10/11 plate joint.
The tank shell was in fair condition with 2 bulges found near the tank floor. The bulges were located at P1/14 plate joint and P7/8 plate joint and do not appear to be detrimental to service at this time and have no leaks but should be monitored for future issues. All plate joint gaskets were found to be dry and brittle but no joint leaks were found at this time. 1 plate joint was found to have bolting with oil seepage at plate 6/7 joint near the top of the plate. Product was found leaking from the roof near the autogauge sheaves. The roof was not accessible for up close inspection at this time. The autogauge appears to be disconnected and out of service at this time.
Recommendations: Remove oil and soil buildup from the foundation. Restore foundation with clean rock and fill in the cavity under the floor. Replace bolting with seepage. Monitor tank for plate joint gasket leaks. Remove the autogauge if it will not be placed back into service.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The floor was in fair condition with over 50 bolts showing signs of corrosion. Corroded bolting should be replaced. One section of the floor was found to have a gap at the plate joint that a scraper could fit through and would leak water or product. Floor pitting was less than .010É?ù at areas where the coating had chipped.
The shell is in fair condition. Shell bolting braces are completely corroded in the lower 12É?ù near the floor at every vertical shell joint and could lead to leaks developing. Shell was covered in oil sludge. Sludge was removed at random and revealed good coating and no corrosion.
The roof is in fair condition. Some areas of coating failure and possible corrosion were noted. No holes were found in the roof.
Recommendations: Replace floor plate 13 and install patches at all MFL hit locations. Touch up paint coating on floor. Replace shell bolting braces. Replace corroded floor bolting and fix gap in floor plates near round manway.
Magnetic Flux Leakage Inspection:
Magnetic Flux Leakage testing was completed on 100% of the floor as accessible. 16 MFL hits were found and proven up with UT. Floor thickness at these areas was below required t-min of .100É?ù. MFL hit locations can be patched with the exception of plate 13 which should be considered for replacement.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell, roof, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 03/31/2016. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 04/01/2016 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There is 1 caution TML per the current thickness reading taken 07/09/2015. The caution TML is due to high corrosion rate and low remaining life at TML 9.03. Some significant thinning is present in the upper course. Recommend internal inspection with scaffolding to allow access to upper course for close-up inspection.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. Externally the shell is insulated 100%, and a full visual inspection on this external shell could not be completed. During this inspection the tank was being steamed out and visual evidence of leakage was found from this process. One location was on the 180 degrees side next to 2‚Äô‚Äô nozzle and other was between 270 degrees and 0 degrees. See page 10, 11 and 12 for location. Recommend removing the insulation in those areas and do further inspection. The tank foundation is a concrete ring above grade level with light to moderate cracking. No settling or spalling was noticed. The anchor bolting is installed in the concrete foundation and no significant problem was found. A cavity was located on the North East side next to the foundation; it looks like it could have been caused by an old steam discharge. No apparent leakage was found on all bolted nozzles or no corrosion was present. There is evidence of past leakage on the 4‚Äô‚Äô foam line. Two ground cables were found securely attached to the tank. The auto gauge is not functional and has been replaced with a liquid head pressure indicator.
The roof access ladder is securely attached to the tank and the paint coating is in fair condition with surface rusting present. Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to limited access. Several areas of the roof have paint coating failure with leakage and corrosion present. Severity of the corrosion could not be assessed due to limited roof access. No excessive sagging was noted. There appear to be a few holes in the roof plates.
Recommendations: Fill in cavity under foundation and remove all loose debris around the tank. Areas of corrosion and leakage should be repaired. Areas of coating failure should be cleaned and recoated. Perform internal inspection at earliest convenience. Remove insulation from suspected leak areas and inspect for holes.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the heads, shell, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the next inspection will be 06/11/2017. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 06/20/2019 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 4 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 06/05/2015.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection was performed and found this vessel to be fit for service. This vessel was in service at the time of this inspection. This vessel‚Äôs exterior shell and head # 2 are fully insulated and found to be in fair condition. A visual external inspection could not be performed on the shell and head #2 on the exterior surface at this time due to the vessel being insulated. The exterior surface condition on head #1 was found to be in fair condition with minor surface rust present. The exterior coating on head #1 is in poor condition with chipping and faded in areas. This vessel is supported by two saddles welded to the vessel and mounted on a concrete pedestal above grade level for a foundation. This support system showed no visible evidence of spalling or any other significant problems present. All anchor bolts are installed in the concrete pedestal and were securely fastened and in good condition. Both ends were single-nutted and one end was slotted with clearance to allow for expansion. Note South West end was missing one anchor nut. Attached piping appeared to be properly supported and no leaks or strains were noted at any of the nozzle locations. All connected piping appeared to be properly supported. A grounding connection was located on the West end saddle support and was found to be in good condition. There is two pressure relief valves protecting this vessel and is located on top of this vessel and both are set at 50 PSI. Note the service tag was on both pressure relief valve and last time they were service was May 2013 and June 2014. There are no signs of past or present leakage noted. The pressure and temperature gauges were found to be intact and legible with no indications of past or present leakage. The vessel data plate was attached and legible. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection.
API 510 Internal Inspection(2013):
Internal visual inspection was completed during this inspection. The shell ID exhibited general corrosion with isolated pitting up to .040‚Äô‚Äô to .090‚Äô‚Äôin depth present. The pitting and corrosion was lightly scattered throughout the bottom of this vessel, and two locations were found at .09‚Äô‚Äô in depth. This condition did not warrant repair at this time. The five vertical baffles located on the East end of vessel were found not securely attached to the shell ID. The fire tubes 2‚Äô‚Äô angle supports on West end next to the head were broken and bent way from the head. The customer made all the necessary arrange to get repairs done on the same day as the inspection was performed. Total Western was called out and made all necessary repairs to the vertical baffles and fire tubes supports. When repairs were completed Applus RTD preformed Dye penetrant testing on all the repairs areas. All repairs were found acceptable. The next internal inspection will be time based at 10 years.
Note: Fire tubes inspected separate from vessel.
UltraPipe Unit ID POSO
UltraPipe Circut ID V-302

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 7/3/2017. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 05/28/2045 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate.
There are 0 caution tml locations per the current thickness reading taken 7/3/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found this vessel to be in fair condition. The shells external OD could not be inspected due to insulation covering the shell at time of inspection. The insulation on this vessels exterior shell is in fair condition; several gaps were found at insulation jacketing seams and sealing around the nozzles is peeling away from the nozzle. The coating on head 1 (fire tube head) is in poor condition and is mostly burned away and the head is covered in surface rusting. All nozzles and threaded connections to this shell have no evidence of leakage. The foundation for this vessel was found to be in good condition and free of spalling. All anchors bolts were securely fastened to the concrete foundation. The vertical ladder on the side of the vessel was structurally sound with no damage noted. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
Recommendations: Repair gaps in insulation and reseal insulation around nozzles as needed
API 510 Internal Inspection: 2013
The vessel was taken out of service, opened, and pressure washed to remove excess product and debris. The fire tubes were removed from the vessel and sent to a lay down location to be sandblasted and inspected. The interior shell and heads were stained with black oily product. No visual evidence of corrosion or pitting was found during this inspection. All welded attachments to shell and head ID appeared to be securely attached and visually found to be structurally sound. All nozzles were clear of any plugging.

Inspection Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 07/02/2017. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 12/31/2032 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate.
There are 0 caution tml locations per the current thickness reading taken 07/02/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found this vessel to be in fair condition. The shell external OD could not be inspected due to insulation covering the shell at time of inspection. The insulation on this vessels exterior shell is loose and not seal around the nozzles. Found to be in fair condition. Head number #1 is insulated. Insulation on head # 1 was found to be missing sheeting cover and insulation in some area over all the insulation on this head is in poor condition. All nozzles and threaded connections to this shell have no evidence of leakage. The foundation for this vessel was found to be in good condition and free of spalling. Anchors bolts on north end west side missing and all other were securely fastened to the concrete foundation. The vertical ladder on the side of the vessel was structurally sound with no damage noted. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
Recommendation: Repair insulation as needed on head number #1. Replace missing nuts on anchor bolting on north end as needed.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
This vessel was taken out of service and blinded off and then the fire tubes were removed and send out to be sandblasted and to be inspected. A pressure washer was used to remove all oily products from shell and heads and the sand pans were removed before the internal inspection. Overall the entire vessel was found to be in clean condition. The visual inspection found this vessel not to be coated internally. The shell and heads were stained from oily product. In the areas where the sand pans were located there was light to moderate internal surface erosion was found and lightly scattered across the full length of the vessel. This erosion was measured and found to be between .030‚Äô‚Äô to .140‚Äô‚Äô in-depth with the exception of one area measured at .200‚Äô‚Äô in-depth and it was found on the North end on the bottom half of the shell and that area will require repair because it is over half the wall loss. The shell wall thickness is 0.375‚Äô‚Äô stamped on manufacturer date plate. One H-Bean for divider plate was found not attached to shell and screen was damaged and will require repair. All the rest of the components and welded attachments accessible to the shell and heads appear to be in sound condition with no visual sign of any damages found.
UltraPIPE Unit ID: HOMEBASE
UltraPIPE Eq/Circ ID: V-302

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the heads, shell, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the next inspection will be 03/23/2016. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 05/09/2017 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 02/05/2015. The next inspection date is half-life based.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection was performed and found this vessel to be in fair condition. This vessel was not in service at the time of inspection. This vessel‚Äôs exterior shell and head #2 are fully insulated and the insulation is in poor condition. Holes have been cut in the insulation in some locations and left open. Bands are missing and there are gaps in the seams between sheets. A visual external inspection could not be performed on the shell and head #2 exterior surfaces at this time due to the vessel being insulated. The exterior surface condition on head #1 in fair condition. The exterior coating is faded and in some areas light to moderate surface rust is present.
This vessel is supported by two saddles welded to the vessel and mounted on a concrete pad above grade level for a foundation. This support system showed no visible evidence of spalling or any other significant problems present. The anchor bolts are installed in the concrete pillars and are in satisfactory condition with exception of the 4 nuts missing. All nozzles and attached piping appear to be in good condition. There is one PSV protecting this vessel and is located on top of this vessel and set at 50 PSI. There are no signs of past or present leakage noted. The pressure and temperature gauges were found to be intact and legible with no indications of past or present leakage. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
Recommendations:
Repair insulation and seal all gaps and holes. Replace missing anchor nuts.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection. Internal inspection was last completed in 2014.

2010 INSPECTION DATA:
{rsfiles path=""data/homebase/dehy/api510/v_305/2010/hovey_v305_summary_051010.pdf""}

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the heads, shell, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the next inspection will be 05/13/2018. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 03/01/2021 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There is 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 07/28/2015. The next inspection is half-life based due to remaining life less than 20 years.
API 510 External Inspection:
The external condition of the vessel was found to be fit for continued service. The north and south concrete foundation pedestals were found to be structurally sound and free from any significant spalling or cracks. Saddle supports were in good condition but were found to have light rust and surface scale present at the base plates. All anchor bolts were secure in the concrete foundation and in good condition. Minor rust was noted at bolt threads. The South end was single nutted and slotted with clearance to allow for expansion. Note North end anchor bolts were missing nuts on both side. Recommend installing the missing nuts on the anchor bolts. This vessel‚Äôs exterior shell and heads are fully insulated and found to be in fair condition with minor damage to insulation sheathing and seal missing around the nozzles. Recommend add seals around the nozzles to protect from CUI are any other future damage to the vessel. A visual external inspection could not be performed on the shell and heads exterior surface at this time do to the vessel being insulated. All nozzles and attached piping appears to be in good condition. There was no PSV on this vessel at time of inspection. This vessel was inactive at the time of this external inspection. There are no signs of past or present leakage noted. The pressure and temperature gauges were found to be intact and legible with no indications of past or present leakage. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 Internal Inspection;
Internal inspection was not completed at this time. The last internal inspection was December 2014.
UltraPipe Unit ID HOMEBASE
UltraPipe Circut ID V-305

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD É?? Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 19 Thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. 18 thickness locations are on the well flow line and 1 on the well casing.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 4/10/2018 based on a default corrosion rate of 2 mills per year.
There is 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 4/11/2013.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in fair condition. This piping circuit externally is insulated and, UT inspection ports were installed at the time of inspection. The condition of the insulation is found to be in poor condition with missing insulation or damage in areas on this piping circuit, and found to be below grade level. This piping circuit is supports by steel pipe in some areas and, the surface was covered with light to moderate surface rust and no corrosion was present. In the existing areas wooden blocks is used to support the piping. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 5 year thickness inspection interval per API requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Note 1 TML location is located on the well casing
Recommendations: Repair insulation as needed. Remove excess soil around the insulation.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID CATFISH

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 3/27/2018. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 11/04/2022 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. There are 24 caution tml locations per the current thickness reading taken 10/1/2013. The next thickness survey will be time based at half-life 4.5 years.
API 510 External Inspection:
This external inspection found this vessel to be in poor condition. The exterior on the shell is insulated, with missing sheeting and allow moisture to be trapped between and causing CUI corrosion on the shell. In some areas were the sheeting is missing CUI was found. The exterior on the heads are coated and in poor condition with surface rust and no visual sign of corrosion present. On the East head on the bottom a repair was made not to API code are any other code. The thickness measurements taken 10/2010 and the new in 10/2013 show a wall lost on the bottom (180) side of the shell. One PSV was located and it was set @ 50 PSI. The foundation and anchors bolting, no significant problem was found. The ladders and platform attached to this vessel visual look to be in sound condition.
Recommendations: Internal inspection needs to be performed at the next outage are before. Make the necessary repair to code and by a qualified company are personnel. Repair or replace the insulation as need and check for CUI corrosion.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were not performed on this vessel at this time. Thickness survey was completed on 11/19/2010. The next thickness inspection date is 11/18/2015. The predicted retirement date is 06/29/2049.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection was not completed during this inspection. An external visual inspection was completed on 11/19/2010.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
This vessel was taken out of service and cleaned before inspection was performed. The shell and heads ID is bare metal covered with a light to moderate black scale build-up throughout this vessel. There is general uniform deep pitting and corrosion with some pits closely spaced together. The pitting was scattered throughout the bottom of the vessel between 5 o‚Äôclock to 7o‚Äô clock. The sand pan cover was not removed during this inspection so a visual inspection could not be performed at this time in that area. The areas of corrosion and pitting ranged from 0.020‚Äô‚Äô to 0.370‚Äô‚Äô deep. The deepest pit was found on the west end of the vessel in the first section at the bottom. This area is over half the estimated original wall thickness of the vessel. A pit gauge was used to measure the depth of corrosion and pitting and the deepest measurement was written down next to each area. All vertical baffle screens in this vessel are welded to the upper shell between the 8:00 and 4:00 position and were intact and structurally sound. All attachment welds to the shell ID were free of any visible cracking. There was some corrosion found on welded attachments. All nozzle IDs were clear of any plugging.
Update 7/27/2012: Sand pan was removed for inspection. The areas were cleaned before inspection was performed on this vessel. Light to moderate corrosion and pitting found ranging from 0.100‚Äô‚Äô to 0.190‚Äô‚Äô deep. Except one area around 2‚Äô‚Äô nozzle on east end of the vessel it was found to be the deepest at .340‚Äô‚Äô. Noted some 2‚Äô‚Äô nozzles located on the bottom of this vessel under the sand pan have evidence of light internal corrosion present in the nozzles.
Recommendations:
Repair pitted and corroded area using weld overlay or a customer approved procedure to repair the damage. After welding perform magnetic particle inspection on repairs as required. Consider coating vessel internally if possible to prevent any further corrosion.
It is recommended that the insulation along the bottom of the vessel be removed and the area under the sand pan be scanned for corrosion in this area.
Repairs and inspection:
V-300 shell and head ID have some measurable pitting and corrosion scattered throughout shell and head ID that range from .005‚Äô‚Äô to .400‚Äô‚Äôin depth, size and shape on the bottom head and shell ID of V-300. Repairs were made by completing weld over-lay in heaviest areas of corrosion and pitting. One flush patch 30‚Äô‚Äô X 30‚Äô‚Äô X .500‚Äô‚Äô was installed with a two inch nozzle. NDE inspection was performed after repairs were made on this vessel. Based on the results of this inspection, this vessel is safe for continued operation.
UltraPipe Unit ID PLAC
UltraPipe Circut ID V-300

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were not performed on this vessel at this time.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection was not completed during this inspection.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
This vessel was taken out of service and cleaned before inspection was performed. The shell and heads ID is bare metal covered with a light to moderate black scale build-up throughout this vessel. There is general uniform deep pitting and corrosion with some pits joining found scattered throughout bottom of this vessel around where the old sand pan used to rest. The areas of corrosion and pitting found ranges from 0.020‚Äô‚Äô to 0.340‚Äô‚Äô deep. The deepest was found on the west end of the vessel on second section at the bottom. This area is over half the estimated original wall thickness on this vessel. A pit gauge was used to measure the depth of corrosion and pitting and the deepest measurement was written down next to each area. All vertical baffle screens in this vessel are welded to upper shell between the 8:00 and 4:00 position and were intact and structurally sound. All attachment welds to the shell ID were free of any visible cracking or corrosion. All nozzle IDs were clear of any plugging; light corrosion was found near the internal nozzle attachment welds on a few of the bottom 2‚Äô‚Äô nozzles.
PMI was completed during the 2010 inspection and the material analysis determined the material to be consistent with SA-516-70. See attached PMI report for detail.
Recommendations: Repair pitted areas and corroded nozzle attachment welds using weld overlay and perform magnetic particle inspection on repairs. Consider coating vessel internal if possible to prevent corrosion.

Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment.

API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. This is the first inspection for this vessel. The paint coating is new and is in good condition, all vessel surfaces are free of any pitting or corrosion. No bulges or deformations were noted in any of the shell or head external surfaces. This vertical vessel is supported by 4 support legs attached to the shell. There is a flat dollar plate welded inside of the vessel just above the bottom head seam which is the bottom pressure boundary for this vessel. The bottom elliptical head is for support of the internal pressure boundary and structure of the vessel. The foundation appears to be sound with no cracking or spalling noted. The attached PSV is in serviceable condition and is set at data plate MAWP of 140PSI. The vessel is properly grounded through a ground cable attached to a support leg.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 11/24/2020. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 10/18/2035 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment.
There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 11/24/2010.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. This is the first inspection for this vessel. The paint coating is new and is in good condition, all vessel surfaces are free of any pitting or corrosion. No bulges or deformations were noted in any of the shell or head external surfaces. This vertical vessel is supported by 4 support legs attached to the shell. There is a flat dollar plate welded inside of the vessel just above the bottom head seam which is the bottom pressure boundary for this vessel. The bottom elliptical head is for support of the internal pressure boundary and structure of the vessel. The foundation appears to be sound with no cracking or spalling noted. The attached PSV is in serviceable condition and is set at data plate MAWP of 140PSI. The vessel is properly grounded through a ground cable attached to a support leg.
UltraPipe Unit ID FAIRFLD
UltraPipe Circut ID V-1209AS

{rsfiles path=""data/placerita/api510/v_600/2012/placerita_v600_repair-report_030512.pdf""}

{rsfiles path=""data/placerita/api510/v_600/2010/v-600_report_121710.pdf""}

Virtual Tour
View in Panorama
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 03/06/2017. The predicted
retirement date of the vessel is 08/31/2022 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken 03/07/2017. The next inspection date is based on CML
thicknesses only and does not take locally thinned areas or holes into consideration.
A pit was found in Manway MW-1 during UT inspection. The lowest thickness found at the pit was .434É?ù and the thickness just
outside of the pit was .587É?ù. The 3 16É?ù manway nozzles were press formed from SA-516-70 Plate. The plate measures
approximately .700É?ù at the edge of the flange. The method of forming these nozzles causes a thickness variance along the
length of the bore making repeat inspections impractical. It is recommended these manways be evaluated for thinning by UT
scanning at each UT survey but not monitored for corrosion.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in fair-poor condition. The vessel is 100% insulated with 1É?ù thick insulation.
Previous inspection port holes were present and visual inspection of the shell was conducted through these holes and through
gaps in the insulation. Several areas along the bottom of the shell have failed paint coating and rusting is present. Signs of
CUI (Corrosion Under Insulation) are present in several locations. Other areas of the shell were in good condition and the
paint coating was still intact. A hole approximately 7/16É?ù diameter and 3/4"" long was found on the east shell
between nozzles N-18 and N-19. No external corrosion is present at this location and the likely cause is
internal corrosion. UT Scanning around the damaged area revealed isolated pitting. Area around pits was
consistent with nominal wall of .375É?ù. Scanning was limited to clean and exposed areas. Additional scanning is
recommended. Supports were in good condition and the anchor bolting is secure. Concrete pedestals are in good condition
with some product and rust stains present. No cracking, chipping or spalling was found in the pedestals. The insulation on the
vessels exterior shell is in fair-poor condition. Several holes and gaps were found in the insulation sheeting and several nozzles
did not have any sealing around the insulation interface. Some areas of insulation were found to be moist and signs of CUI
were present. It is highly likely that water intrusion is coming from gaps and holes in the insulation and a lack of sealing
around nozzles.
Recommendations:
Perform complete internal inspection as soon as possible to determine extent of internal corrosion and identify other trouble
areas. Remove insulation along bottom of vessel to determine extent of CUI. Consider removing all insulation and recoating
the vessel, then reinsulating. Consider coating handrails, platforms and ladders.
Recommendations:
Perform complete internal inspection as soon as possible to determine extent of internal corrosion and identify other trouble
areas. Remove insulation along bottom of vessel to determine extent of CUI. Consider removing all insulation and recoating
the vessel, then reinsulating. Consider coating handrails, platforms and ladders.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was completed on 08/09/2012 by Ronnie Harleston. Internal surfaces were covered with a light to
moderate hard black scale build-up. Bottom area had a rust scale buildup which was randomly removed revealing light to
moderate corrosion and pitting. Several areas of deep pitting and general corrosion were found along the bottom of the vessel
from the 5:00 to 7:00 position. Pitting ranges from .020É?ù to .390É?ù in depth. A through-wall pit was found on the east
end near a 6É?ù nozzle. All areas of corrosion found were measured with a pit gauge and the depth of the defect was written
next to it. Some corrosion was found on the internal 2É?ù piping. All baffles and support welds are in good condition and show
no signs of corrosion or cracking. The 16É?ù manway on the east end has moderate corrosion on the ID of the manway.
Recommendations : Sandblast internal surfaces and completely clean out any scale or product buildup and reinspect. Repair
holes and any corrosion or pitting in the shell deeper than .200É?ù. Perform magnetic particle inspection of the repair areas.
Update 08/21/2012:
All internal piping and other internal attachments were removed and the bottom half of the vessel ID was sandblasted. The internal surfaces were re-inspected post sand blast. Re-inspection revealed additional areas of corrosion in the bottom shell and another through-wall hole on the east end of the vessel at the bottom. Deep pitting was found with a depth of over .300É?ù leaving very little remaining wall at these locations. All locations of pitting and corrosion were gauged and marked.
Recommendations:
Repair pitting with depth between .080É?ù to .250É?ù deep and large areas of corrosion up to .125É?ù deep by weld overlay. Repair through-wall holes, large areas of corrosion greater than .125É?ù deep and deep pitting greater than .250É?ù deep by flush patch shell replacement. Flush patches must be radiographed in accordance with original design code. Weld overlay should be inspected by Magnetic Particle prior to placing vessel back into service. All repair work and the amount of NDE should be approved by Berry Petroleum engineering prior to the start of repair.
Update 08/21/2012:
All internal piping and other internal attachments were removed and the bottom half of the vessel ID was sandblasted. The internal surfaces were re-inspected post sand blast. Re-inspection revealed additional areas of corrosion in the bottom shell and another through-wall hole on the east end of the vessel at the bottom. Deep pitting was found with a depth of over .300É?ù leaving very little remaining wall at these locations. All locations of pitting and corrosion were gauged and marked.
Recommendations:
Repair pitting with depth between .080É?ù to .250É?ù deep and large areas of corrosion up to .125É?ù deep by weld overlay. Repair through-wall holes, large areas of corrosion greater than .125É?ù deep and deep pitting greater than .250É?ù deep by flush patch shell replacement. Flush patches must be radiographed in accordance with original design code. Weld overlay should be inspected by Magnetic Particle prior to placing vessel back into service. All repair work and the amount of NDE should be approved by Berry Petroleum engineering prior to the start of repair.

All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 12/01/2020. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 07/17/2120 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment.
There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 12/02/2010.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. This is the first inspection for this vessel. The paint coating is new and is in good condition, all vessel surfaces are free of any pitting or corrosion. No bulges or deformations were noted in any of the shell or head external surfaces. This vertical vessel is supported by 4 support legs attached to the shell. There is a flat dollar plate welded inside of the vessel just above the bottom head seam which is the bottom pressure boundary for this vessel. The bottom elliptical head is for support of the internal pressure boundary and structure of the vessel. The foundation appears to be sound with no cracking or spalling noted. The attached PSV is in serviceable condition and is set at data plate MAWP of 140PSI. The vessel is properly grounded through a ground cable attached to a support leg.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Internal ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the floor. A-Scan readings were performed using an Olympus 38 DL Plus with a D-791-RM search unit utilizing echo-echo mode to receive true wall readings through paint. These baseline measurements have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 10/01/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 03/27/2034 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 10/01/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. The coating is in good condition. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The retaining wall is in sound condition and secure. Light soil buildup was found in the rock wall and on the chime. A small cavity was found near the ground cable.?ˇ Gasket failure was evident on one of the 1É?ù sample threaded connections.?ˇ All vertical & horizontal bolted seams were in good condition with no signs of leaks or failed gaskets. Nozzles and are in good condition with good paint coverage.?ˇ The coned roof is in good condition and a pressure relief device was found. Access-way stairs are in good condition & secure with complete paint coverage. Ground cable is secure.
Recommendations:
Suggest filling in cavity near the ground cable.
Replace gasket on 1É?ù sample threaded connection.
Remove any soil debris covering the chime.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection has found the equipment to be fit for service and in good condition. Paint coating is in good condition.?ˇ No holidays were found.?ˇ All floor plate bolted seams are in good condition with protective bolt caps. No corrosion can be noted at this time due to the amount paint protecting all surfaces inside the tank.?ˇ The roof rafters appear in good condition as seen from the floor.?ˇ Separator wall supports are secure and structurally sound. Center roof support is coated and in good condition.?ˇ Internal piping is properly supported and in good condition.?ˇ The shell walls were not cleaned prior to this inspection, The inspector cleaned random locations and no problems were found.?ˇ Coating on the wall is also in good condition. The cleanout and manway nozzles have coating failure and if any problems should occur they might start there. The base metal is in good condition and no surface rust was found.
Recommendations:
None
UltraPipe Unit ID FAIRFLD
UltraPipe Circut ID T-1201A

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 08/22/2023. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 04/26/2031 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 12/17/2015. The next thickness survey is half-life based.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The external paint coating is in good condition. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The retaining wall is lifted on the south side and the rock fill has spilled out. No evidence of a bottom leak was found. 2 vertical seams have evidence of leaks coming from the bolts; on the north west side at the bottom of the 2nd course there is evidence of a leak and there is a temporary patch installed; on the north east side at the top of the first course there is evidence of a slow leak. The ‚ÄúConfined Space‚Äù signs above the manways are weathered. The nozzle on the south side of the tank does not have a blind flange installed.
The roof access stairway is securely attached to the tank. Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to limited access.
Recommendations: Repair damaged foundation on the south side and re-fill the spilled rock. At the next scheduled outage, repair the 2 seam leaks found using permanent repairs. Replace ‚ÄúConfined Space‚Äù signs. Install a blind flange on the nozzle on the south side.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. No record of an internal inspection is on file. The first internal inspection will be due in 2020. An internal inspection should be completed at the next opportunity to obtain baseline readings on the floor and inspect for possible causes of the vertical seam leaks.
UltraPipe Unit ID FAIRFLD
UltraPipe Circut ID T-1207

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 03/27/2021 for the shell and 12/29/2021 for the floor. The predicted retirement date is 07/08/2026 for the shell and 09/29/2027 for the floor based on calculated corrosion rate and a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness survey taken 12/18/2015 for the shell and 03/30/2016 for the floor. The next thickness survey will be half-life based.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. The shell shows no signs of bulging or other damage. The external coating is in good condition. A temperature gauge on the east side appears to be non-operational. The crushed rock retaining ring is pulled up on the south side and the rock fill has spilled out creating a void under the tank. The shell plate seams do not have any signs of leaks. Nozzles are in good condition. The roof access stairway is in good condition. A visual of the roof was completed from the platform. Roof is in good condition and no holes, coating failure, corrosion, or sagging was noted. The roof plates were free of any product buildup. The breather vent screen is out of place.
Recommendations:
Repair foundation ring and restore rock fill under tank on the south side. Repair the breather screen. Replace defective temperature gauge on east side. The next external will be due 03/30/2021.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found the tank to be in overall good condition with some repairs required prior to returning to service. There were 2 holes found, both in floor plate P9-1 (see drawing for location). Plates P7-1 and P8-1 have several areas of corrosion ranging from .080‚Äù deep to .120‚Äù deep. Plate P16-2 has 1 area with corrosion up to .100‚Äù deep. All locations requiring repairs have been marked on the plate in red. All floor plates were covered in small coating blisters. Some of the blisters had broken open exposing plate below. These locations were marked on the plate in yellow. The cleanout door on the west side has large blisters in the coating but no corrosion was observed. Floor bolting was in good condition.
Shell plates were covered in product scale and were not able to be inspected at this time. Shell bolting was in good condition. Internal diffusers on the inlets and outlets were in good condition and show no signs of damage. The roof plates appear to be in good condition and no obvious signs of corrosion were noted. Rafters are in good condition. The center support post has heavy product buildup but appears to be in good condition.
Recommendations:
Repair holes and corroded areas in plates P9-1, P7-1, P8-1, and P16-2. Repair floor coating at areas marked on the floor plates (reference drawing for locations). Repair coating in clean out door on west side. For the next inspection, consider having the floor sandblasted prior to inspection to inspect for plate corrosion under the coating blisters and then recoat the floor after the inspection has been completed.
The next internal inspection will be due 12/29/2021, based on half-life.
UltraPipe Unit ID FAIRFLD
UltraPipe Circut ID T-1213A

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell, floor, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 05/17/2026 on the shell and 02/16/2036 on the floor. The predicted retirement date is 08/17/2036 for the shell and 12/24/2061 for the floor based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 02/16/2016.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. Nozzles on shell were found to be in good condition. Repads on nozzles were found to be in good condition with weep holes clear. Flanges and bolts on nozzles are in good condition. Tank sits on a concrete foundation. Area on south side of tank concrete foundation has vegetation. All external welds on the shell are sound and in good condition. Coating on Tank is found to be in good condition. Overflow line is properly supported and drains away from tank foundation.
The roof access stairway is in good condition. External roof rafters were found to be in good condition. P/V hatch was found to be in good condition. Vent on roof was found to be in good condition.
Recommendations: Have vegetation around south side concrete foundation removed.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to be in good condition. Coating on shell, roof, nozzles, and floor was found overall in good condition. 1 area on floor plate 1 and 4 weld was found with a coating chip. Internal of nozzles were found to be in good condition and coated. All internal welds were found to be coated and in good condition. Roof was found to be in good condition.
Recommendations: Touch up coating on the weld for plate 1 to plate 4.

{rsfiles path=""data/placerita/api653/t_9/2011/plac_tank9_summary_050211.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/placerita/api653/t_9/2011/plac_tank9_ultrapipe_050211.pdf""}

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 10/22/2023. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 01/21/2031 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken 07/22/2016.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The external coating is in fair condition with several areas of product stains and light surface rusting. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The steel retaining wall looks to be intact and structurally sound. Hard oily product and soil buildup was found within the rock ring and covering the retaining wall in various areas. Oily product buildup was cleared in areas around the chime and surface rusting with light corrosion was found. Several vertical seam leaks were noted possibly caused by loose bolting or failed gaskets. Seam gaskets show signs of deterioration and cracking. Some nozzles show signs of past leakage via stained areas and nozzle 12 is missing bolts on the blind flange.
Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to limited access. No excessive sagging was noted.
Recommendations: Oily product buildup should be cleared out from the rock ring. Areas of coating failure should be cleaned and recoated. Replace damaged plate gaskets and check bolting torque as necessary.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. The first internal inspection is due in 2020.
UltraPipe Unit ID PLAC
UltraPipe Circuit ID TK-9
