Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the floor. A-Scan readings were performed using an Olympus 38 DL Plus with a D-791-RM search unit utilizing echo-echo mode to receive true wall readings through paint. During the internal inspection, data received from A-scan UT crew found that each plate around the center two plates is approximately 0.100É?ù thick and the two center plates (C-1 & C-2) is approximately 0.130É?ù thick. One reading was recorded as 0.098É?ù in plate 10. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 11/01/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 7/29/2027 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank in good condition. The roof is in good condition with light debris from the sample hatch. The external paint coating on the shell is in good condition with regards to some minor scratches from the sample station resting on the tank shell and from other maintenance work. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The retaining wall is in sound condition and secure. Light soil buildup was found around the chime. One vertical seam was found having some debris on the shell and appears that it had leaked from the gasket at that location in the past. This location is on the same stave as the cleanout on the right vertical seam. One bolt was noticed with rust and debris on and around it, this is found just to the left of the cleanout on the vertical seam. The gasket around that bolt may have failed in the past and leaked at that location but at this time the debris was dry. Some oil debris was found around bolted flanged connections. Multiple ground cables were found. Two of them were loose. New pumps were found and new nozzles were installed. Access-way is in good condition and secure.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection has found the tank floor in poor condition. It appears the coating was either incorrectly applied or a manufactures defect. The paint did not fully adhere to the base metal of the tank floor or the cleanout or manway. Mass clusters of tiny coating blisters were found throughout the tank floor, manway and cleanout. After investigation of the larger blisters on the floor, three pits and one hole was discovered. Two pits were 0.070É?ù deep and the third is 0.030É?ù deep. Remaining wall at the two deeper pits is approximately 0.030É?ù. These are located on plate 8 & plate 13. The hole was discovered on the center plate (C-2) between the seam of plate 17 & 18. Plates 11, 12, 14, 15 & 16 including the clean out and manways contained mass clusters of tiny blisters and after investigation of these small clusters of blisters the material appeared un-corroded at the random areas of inspection. On plate 9, three impact concavities were found measuring 0.270É?ù, 0.250É?ù & 0.050É?ù deep. Paint failure was found but no pitting was found at these locations and it appears something fell from above. Multiple cracked bolt protector caps were found throughout the floor. The shell has multiple areas of paint failure near the liquid level line. No blisters were found on the shell. Multiple bolt protector caps on the shell were cracked and missing. The center roof support and rafters are in good condition.
Recommendations:
Sand blast the floor for further evaluation, replace or patch pits and holes & re-coat with appropriate coating
Update 11/14/2012:
The entire tank floor removed and a new tank floor was installed due to excessive corrosion and holes found in the original floor. The new floor is of similar design to the old floor. The coating on the new floor is in good condition with no signs of chipping or blistering.
New baseline thickness readings were established on the floor and the data was entered into UltraPIPE. After review of the new data, the next inspection date for this tank will be 11/14/2017. The predicted retirement date of this tank is 07/29/2027 based on a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate.
UltraPipe Unit ID PLAC
UltraPipe Circuit ID TK-34

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-scan thickness survey was completed on the floor. 6 readings were taken on each floor plate. All readings were entered into UltraPIPE and the next inspection date will be 03/16/2020. The predicted retirement date is 03/15/2020 based on a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. The next inspection will be time based at 5 years to determine a corrosion rate.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
The tank was removed from service and a shell plate was unbolted to allow for cleaning and inspection. The shell and floor were pressure washed prior to inspection. The floor and shell has complete coating failure scattered throughout the shell and floor. No corrosion or pitting was found on the floor or shell. No bulging or other deformations were found in the floor or shell. All bolting was found intact and securely fastened with now significant metal loss noted. The internal baffle has a broken support brace which used to be connected to the center support post. No pads were found under the baffle supports to protect the floor from mechanical damage. The underside of the roof is in good condition with no signs of corrosion, pitting, or holes noted. The roof paint coating is in good condition.
Recommendations:
Sandblast and re-coat the shell and floor. Add support pads or wood blocks under the baffle supports to prevent damage to the floor. Repair broken support brace for baffle at the center support post.
UltraPipe Unit ID ETHEL_D
UltraPipe Circuit ID STC T-6100 / T-6100 FLOOR

Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the floor. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 05/31/2020. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 05/31/2025 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken 06/01/2015. API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection was not completed at this. The next external inspection is due 07/29/2018.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
This tank was taken out of service, opened up, and cleaned out before this internal inspection was performed. Internal inspection found this tank to be in good condition with the exception of coating failure found on 70% of the tank floor. The shell also has some areas of coating failure. In areas were the coating is missing or chipping there is no visual sign of corrosion or pitting present. All shell and floor bolting is in place and secure. All gaskets are in place and appear to be in good condition. No evidence of shell leaks is present. The underside of the roof is in good condition with only minor rusting noted on hardware. No coating issues were visible. The roof supports appear to be in good condition.
Recommendations:
Clean up areas of coating failure and re-apply coating.
The next internal inspection will be half-life based and is due on 05/31/2020.
UltraPipe Unit ID ETHEL_D
UltraPipe Circuit ID T-6200_FLOOR

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 04/24/2021. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 05/15/2100 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. The next thickness inspection will be time based at 10 years
There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 04/25/2011.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. The paint coating is in good condition and all vessel surfaces are free of any pitting or corrosion. No bulges or deformations were noted in any of the shell or head external surfaces. This vertical vessel is supported by 4 legs welded to the bottom head and shell and is secured to the concrete foundation with 4 anchor bolts. The foundation appears to be sound with no cracking or spalling noted. The PSV protecting this vessel is set at 60 PSI which is below the data plate MAWP of 203PSI. A dedicated ground is in place and attached to the vessel supports. The next external inspection will be time based at 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID Panfee
UltraPipe Circut ID D-4006

All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 04/24/2021. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 09/28/2099 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. The next thickness inspection will be time based at 10 years

API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. The paint coating is in good condition, all vessel surfaces are free of any pitting or corrosion. No bulges or deformations were noted in any of the shell or head external surfaces. This vertical vessel is supported by a skirt welded to the bottom head and is secured to the concrete foundation with 4 anchor bolts. The foundation appears to be sound with no cracking or spalling noted. No PSV was found attached to this vessel or attached piping. Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and due to a lack of design data, a next inspection date could not be determined. Maximum Allowable Operating Pressure (MAOP) is 243 PSI based on default stress values allowed by API 510 code.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. The paint coating is in good condition with areas of chipping and peeling on shell and head surfaces. Light surface rusting was noted in areas where coating has failed. All vessel surfaces are free of any pitting or corrosion. No bulges or deformations were noted in any of the shell or head external surfaces. This vertical vessel is supported by a skirt welded to the bottom head and is secured to the concrete foundation with 4 anchor bolts. The foundation appears to be sound with no cracking or spalling noted. A 2É?ù PSV is installed on piping attached to the top nozzle of this vessel. The PSV was not accessible for close-up visual inspection at this time. A dedicated grounding connection was found attached to the vessel support. No data plate was attached to this vessel and no design data is available. California Code of Regulations requires that all vessels operating above 15 PSI must be stamped in accordance with the applicable code of construction.
UltraPipe Unit ID Panfee
UltraPipe Circut ID Gas Scrubber

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD É?? Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 110 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) in 16 piping circuits were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data earliest inspection due date will be 01/31/2021 on circuit WF-1301B. The earliest predicted retirement date will be 12/15/2045 on circuit WF-1301. Retirement dates are based on an average of the lowest 25% of TMLs on each circuit. Next inspection will be time based at 10 years.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness readings taken on 02/01/2011 thru 02/14/2011.
API 570 Visual Inspection
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. This piping circuit was constructed in the beginning of 2011 and this is the initial baseline inspection of this circuit. The piping in this circuit was not coated at the time of this inspection and a coating is recommended to protect against external corrosion. All piping appeared to be properly supported and anchored. This circuit is protected from overpressure by PSVs located on attached equipment. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.

Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD established procedures. 139 Thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into UltraPIPE and after review of the data next inspection will be 06/05/2019 based on a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. API 570 Visual Inspection: \t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
This piping circuit has been completely replaced since the last inspection. New baselines were completed on the new circuit. Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. This piping circuit is not insulated and has a factory coating. In the areas around the welds, light surface rust was found. The piping is supported by steel structure supports and found to be placed properly and secure. Certain supports are coated and others are not. Overall the piping supports are in fair condition. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 5 year thickness inspection interval until a corrosion rate can be established.
\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.\t\t\t

The code of construction and design pressure is not known at this time therefore a next inspection date cannot be established.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
This 10É??É?? Sedlaced line is still under construction at the time of inspection. This new 10É??É?? Sedlacek line will replace existing 10É??É?? Sedlacek line that is in service at this time. The new line is running on the same pipe support as the old existing line. Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be 80 % completed at this time. This piping circuit is not coated at this time and the piping is cover with light to moderate surface rust on 100% of the piping. No visual external corrosion or pitting was found. This piping is supported by steel structure support and in fair condition and no corrosion are pitting was found on piping supports. There are no shoes attached to this piping. The piping is resting on top of the support and not clamp down to pipe support. Ultrasonic A- Scan thickness measurement was performed on this line to established baseline and corrosion rate for the new piping. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might Reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 10 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 2 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Recommendations: Complete a visual inspection once the line is completed and placed into service.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
Update 10/01/12: Road crossings were completed and additional TMLÉ??s were taken at the road crossings. The line is currently blinded at both ends and not in service.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD established procedures. 27 Thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be after repairs. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 4 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 02/22/2016 due to 1 tml being below TMIN and 3 tml‚Äôs having a high corrosion rate.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
This piping circuit was found to be in good condition. A section of this piping circuit has been replaced with new piping. See field drawing for locations. New base line readings were taken on the new section of piping. The external piping surface is not coated and is covered with light to moderate brown surface rust. No external corrosion was present. All bolted flanges and threaded connections were found to be free of leakage and were intact, with no significant thread or fastener degradation found. The piping is supported by pipe supports, with no significant problem found. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses, and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 1 year thickness inspection interval per customer. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Recommendations: Tml‚Äôs 1 and 2 are close to the minimum thickness requirements and are showing a high corrosion rate. Tml 3 is below tmin and needs to be replaced. Replacing all three at the same time can reduce shutting down this line and associated cost. And will extend the life of this line.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID FXW
UltraPipe Circut ID GAS INJ WELL E-3

Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD É?? Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 26 Thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
This piping was found with 2 leaking areas TML 14 and 21 both have product leaking and need repair.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
This piping circuit is found to have areas of concern at TML #14 and TML#21 these areas have evidence of product leaking from the piping. The areas of concern UT A Scan was performed and determined to have internal corrosion present; from this inspection the piping circuit is found not fit for service. The piping circuit external is covered with light to moderate brown surface rust and no external corrosion present. The piping is support by attached piping and pipe support, with no significant problem found. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses, and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 1 year thickness inspection interval per customer. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Recommendation: Replace piping circuit as needed.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD established procedures. Thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date could not be determined due to thickness readings below t-min. There are 7 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 02/06/2015. 5 TMLs are below T-min. 2 TMLs have high corrosion rates.
API 570 Visual Inspection
One area was found to have evidence of product leaking from the piping. This area was UT A Scanned and determined to have internal corrosion present; from this inspection the piping circuit is found not fit for service. See field drawing for locations. There are 5 thickness reading locations found below t-min of .120‚Äô‚Äô for this piping circuit. See Ultra pipe survey report for TML locations. This piping circuit is constructed of 3 different kinds of material. Carbon steel located at the well head and the 6‚Äô‚Äô sour gas headers. HDPE plastic piping and stainless steel running between the well head and 6‚Äô‚Äô sour gas header. This piping circuit is found to be in fair condition. The carbon steel external piping surface is not coated and covered with light to moderate surface rust and no external corrosion was present. All bolted flanges and threaded connection with found free of any leakage and intact, with no significant thread or fastener degradation found. The piping is support by attached piping and pipe supports, with no significant problems found. The stainless steel piping is running at grade level with no piping support. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses, and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 5 year visual inspection interval per API-570 Class 2 Piping. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Recommendation: Coat the piping circuit. Replace section with leaks. Replace sections below t-min.
UltraPipe Unit ID FXW
UltraPipe Circut ID GAS INJ WELL GD2

API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. The external paint coating is in good condition with a couple areas of light product stains. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The retaining wall has split on the west side. No rock fill is spilling out. There are weeds, oily rags, and oil build up in and around the crushed rock ring. Soil appeared to have been dug up and has a small void on the north side. There is a 1‚Äù nipple coupling with a cap that has a small drip leak. No NFPA hazard diamond was found on the tank. The roof access stairway is securely attached to the tank and the paint coating is in good condition. Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to limited access. There are a couple of small rust stains around a couple of the roof nozzles from the bolting. There are some small sections of minor sagging in the roof that do not affect the roof drainage. There are signs of previous seepage at some of the bolting on the shell seams; no active leaks were noted at this time. There is an equalizer line that installation was never completed. It was never connected to the tank and is just sitting against it and it should be either installed completely or removed. It could potentially cause corrosion on the shell. The confined space sign on the north cleanout door is faded and not legible.\t\t\t\t
Recommendations:\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
Clear out oil build-up, oily rags and weeds from the rock ring and surrounding areas. Repair the rock ring retaining wall where it has split on the west side. Fill in the dug up area of the foundation on the north side to prevent foundation settlement. Repair the leaking 1‚Äù cap on the north side. Replace the confined space sign on the north cleanout door. Add an NFPA hazard placard to the shell.
The next external visual inspection will be due 07/08/2021.\t\t\t\t
\t\t\t\t
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. The first internal inspection will be due in 2021.\t\t\t
UltraPipe Unit ID POSO
UltraPipe Circut ID T-6100

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 01/03/2021 for the shell and 04/25/2018 for the floor. The predicted retirement date is 07/05/2025 for the shell and 12/31/2028 for the floor based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 07/05/2016 for the shell and 07/07/2011 for the floor.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The shell is insulated and the insulation is in poor condition. Large sections of sheeting and batting are missing. On the East side, the sheeting is covered in oil and the batting is saturated in oil. It appears at some point the tank was overfilled and oil spilled out of the sample hatch and ran down the side of the tank. Portions of the shell where the insulation is missing were found to be in good condition with no signs of corrosion or other damage. The temperature gauge on the east side has cracked glass. The foundation is almost completely buried in soil and oil and the chime cannot be inspected at this time. There is some standing oil on the east side which is likely left over from a line replacement just recently completed. Nozzles on the south side have oil buildup which may also be left over from the line replacement. The roof is in good condition and there are no signs of holes, corrosion or excessive sagging.
Recommendations: Clean out soil and oil buildup from foundation and replace with clean rock fill. Grade the area around the foundation so the steel ring is above grade and so that runoff will be drained away from the tank. Replace missing sections of insulation. Replace all soiled insulation. Seal the insulation around the nozzles. Consider removing all shell insulation and inspect for shell seam leaks. Remove standing oil and any other flammables from the foundation. Replace the temperature gauge on the east side.
The next external visual inspection is due 07/05/2021.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. The next internal inspection is due 04/25/2018.

Comments: \t\t\t\t
Note 08/27/2012: This tank has been taken out of service in August 2012 per Tye Hammond.\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
\t\t\t\t
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey: \t\t\t\tUltrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next thickness inspection date will be 07/18/2014 due to low thickness readings and localized thinning. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 05/18/2024 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 08/15/2011.\t\t\t\t
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in poor condition. The external paint coating is in poor condition with several areas of coating failure and through-wall corrosion. 3 leaks were noted on the 2nd ring on the west side of the tank. Thickness readings were taken adjacent to leaks and lowest readings were recorded: .096É?ù on plate 19, .085É?ù on plate 20 and .068É?ù on plate 21. The tank foundation is crushed rock with a steel retaining ring. Heavy soil and vegetation buildup was noted within the rock ring and is covering the chime in places. Soil buildup was cleared from the chime and some light corrosion was noted beneath the buildup. The tank chime area is in fair condition with several areas of coating failure and light corrosion noted. Slight bulges near the bottom of the tank were noted. All bolted seem gaskets appear to be in fair condition; however some leaks were noted at 2 seams in the second ring likely due to loose bolting or failed gaskets. A corroded area was noted around nozzle N-16 attachment to the shell. The gasket on this nozzle is in poor condition and there is corrosion in this area at .100É?ù deep. Nominal thickness of this plate is .135É?ù. Thickness readings were taken adjacent to the corroded area and the lowest reading recorded was .075É?ù. Some seepage was also noted around nozzle attachment bolts. The target board is in good condition; however, the level indicator cable has broken off of the indicator and is no longer functional.\t\t\t\t
The roof access ladder is in good condition and is secured to the tank. The tank roof is in poor condition. Heavy corrosion was noted on several roof attachments and several areas have corroded completely through. One roof nozzle has corroded and fallen through the roof. Several patches were noted on the roof with significant corrosion around attachment bolting. No areas of significant sagging were noted and there is no evidence of poor roof drainage.\t\t\t\t
Recommendations: Remove tank from service and perform a full internal inspection. Replace plates with general corrosion and thinning. Patch leaks and areas of localized corrosion. Replace roof plates and patch holes as needed. Clean soil and vegetation buildup from around chime and from within rock ring. Clean areas of coating failure and recoat tank to prevent further external corrosion. Patch or replace plate 16 due to excessive external corrosion around nozzle N-16. Check bolting torque at seams with leaks and replace gaskets as necessary. Repair or replace target board indicator. A follow-up inspection will be required once repairs have been completed\t\t\t\t
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended as soon as possible to assess the complete condition of the tank.
UltraPipe Unit ID HOMEBASE
UltraPipe Circut ID T-1000

Comments:
As of 12/04/2012 this tank has been taken out of service per Tye Hammond.
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the floor plates without holes. All readings added to the previous survey completed in 2011. A next inspection date could not be established due to holes in some floor plates. Once repairs have been completed, a re-inspection should be done to establish the next inspection date. The current thickness readings on undamaged plates is consistent with a nominal thickness of .135É?ù.
API 653 External Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The floor is in poor condition with 15 plates found with through wall holes. Several blisters were found in the floor coating and when the coating was removed at these locations, holes were found beneath the coating. The coating was otherwise not damaged which indicates the holes may have been caused by soil-side corrosion.
Internal shell plates were in good condition but were still covered in product buildup so an accurate assessment could not be completed. Clean areas were inspected and revealed no evidence of coating failure, corrosion or pitting. No signs of shell plate bulging or other deformations were noted. Shell and floor plate gaskets appear to be in good condition with no signs of leaks present.
The roof support structure was in good condition with no signs of damage or thinning found. Heavy product buildup was still present on the underside of the roof so an accurate assessment could not be completed. No visible signs of sagging or other damage were noted. Support bracket for the 8É?ù internal fill line was found completely detached from the piping and hanging from the clip attached to the shell.
Recommendations: Remove internal heater piping to complete MFL inspection of the floor to determine if soil side corrosion is present. Reattach support to 8É?ù internal fill line. Replace floor plates with holes. Complete a re-inspection of the floor once repairs have been completed.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the floor. The shell, roof and nozzles were previously inspected in 2011. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 09/18/2018. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 02/12/2033 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 09/18/2013.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection was not completed at this time. Inspection previously completed in 2011.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The floor is in good condition with no signs of corrosion or pitting. Floor coating is good and all bolting is good with no signs of metal loss.
The lower 2 courses of the shell are in good condition with no signs of leaks or corrosion. The 3rd course near the roof has 2 areas that are bowed out and splitting at the seams. These plates are damaged and should be replaced. The cleanout cover plate is bent and corroded.
The roof also has 2 locations that are bowed out and splitting open at the seams causing the plates to not rest on the supports. 3 of the support rafters show signs of thinning but were not accessible for upclose inspection.
The tank appears to have been over pressured which would be the cause of the shell and roof plate damage. The cause of the overpressure is unknown but could possibly have been caused by a failing vent.
Recommendations: Replace damaged roof and shell plates. Provide means to inspect rafters up close and determine if severe corrosion is present. Service pressure/vacuum vents to ensure proper operation. Repair damage to roof insulation and ensure adequate sealing to prevent water intrusion. Replace cleanout cover.
UltraPipe Unit ID HOMEBASE
UltraPipe Circut ID T-51

API 653 External Inspection:

680.31 KB
Comments:
This tank is out of service and scheduled for demolition per Tye Hammond 04-29-2013
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 08/17/2016. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 05/14/2025 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken 08/18/2011
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The external paint coating is in fair condition with areas of light product stains. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. Soil buildup was found in the rock ring and built-up on the chime. Paint coating failure and light corrosion was noted along the chime likely caused by soil buildup. Oil buildup was noted under the chime and could indicate a tank bottom leak or bottom to shell seam leak. Seepage was noted on bolting throughout the tank and the manway gasaket is leaking. Tank seam gaskets are in fair condition and show signs of cracking in places and could be a possible cause of leakage. A leak was noted on plate 12 in the 3rd ring. The thickness adjacent to the leak is .082É?ù. The target board is in good condition and is functional.
The roof access ladder is in good condition and is secured to the tank. Tank roof inspection was limited to visual from a distance due to limited roof access. Significant corrosion was noted near bolted joints and around nozzles. Corrosion in some locations has caused deck deformations. No holes were noted in the roof deck surface. Some roof attachments have significant corrosion and may not be in good working order.
Recommendations: Remove tank from service and complete a full internal inspection to assess the condition of internal surfaces and extent of corrosion. Thoroughly inspect the roof and floor for underside corrosion. Service pressure/vacuum relief vents. Soil and vegetation buildup in rock ring should be cleared. Evaluate and replace gaskets as needed. Check torque on bolted seam bolts.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is highly recommended at the earliest convenience.
UltraPipe Unit ID HOMEBASE
UltraPipe Circuit ID T-1300

The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The shell is insulated and the insulation has areas that need to be repaired. The insulation sheeting is deteriorating and pulling away from tank at nozzle 11. This is due to the insulation banding being held together with carbon wire, rather than the correct stainless binding material. It is recommended to make repairs to the sheeting and bands. Some light product stains were found on the insulation possibly indicating leaks. Insulation sealing has peeled away from the sample box and should be resealed. The tank foundation is crushed rock with a steel retaining ring. The retaining ring and the outer retaining wall appear to be in good condition. The tank chime and coarse ring ledges are covered by insulation and could not be inspected at this time, it is recommended that insulation be removed around the shell to inspect the chime and around the course ring joints. No dedicated grounding connection was found. A proper grounding cable should be attached to the tank.
The roof access stairs were in good condition and show no signs of corrosion. The roof was only accessible from the stairway and a limited visual inspection was completed from the access platform. Visible areas of the roof appeared to be in good condition and the roof is built with external rafters for support. No signs of corrosion, sagging or bulging were noted on roof surfaces. The thief hatch and pressure/vacuum relief valves appear to be in good condition but were not accessible for up-close inspection.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the next inspection date will be 08/23/2016. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 08/23/2022 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There is 0 caution TML location per the current thickness reading taken 08/24/2011. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The external paint on exposed nozzles is in fair condition with areas of missing/failed coating and surface rusting. The nozzles do not appear to have any signs of leakage; the nozzles are threaded with 150 class flange. The tank shell insulation is in poor condition with several areas of loose and damaged sheeting. Insulation is not sealed around several nozzles and could lead to moisture intrusion. The tank foundation is crushed rock with a steel retaining ring. Heavy soil build-up and debris were found within the ring wall; the ring wall is no longer visible due to soil build up. It is recommended the dirt and debris be removed, soil leveled, and rock bed refilled to prevent standing water from forming around the tank. The chime is covered with insulation and some of the insulation should be removed to allow for inspection. The dirt secondary containment dike appears to be in good condition with no signs of damage. A dedicated grounding wire was not found or present during this inspection, possibly buried under foundation soil build-up. Locate grounding wire if there is one attached or install dedicated ground if it is missing. A shell patch was found just above ground level on the west side of the tank. An internal visual inspection is recommended to assess the condition of the shell and identify areas of corrosion. The temperature gauge on the south side near the manway is not legible and should be replaced.
The roof access stairway is in good condition with no corrosion or pitting noted. The tank roof is constructed from rectangular panels and is in good condition. No external corrosion, bulging or sagging was noted. This tank is does not have a pressure relief valve; however it does have a thief hatch attached to the north side of roof. This thief hatch is providing pressure and vacuum relief for this tank.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and floor. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 08/24/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 06/25/2035 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 08/24/2017.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be out of service for repair. The insulation was removed from this tank and then partially replaced at the time of inspection. The coating on this tank was found to be in poor condition on existing plates with brand new coating on new plates. The coating at the bottom to shell joint area has failed and surface rusting with light corrosion is present. Several panels were replaced during this downtime; course 1 panels 3 through 10 and course 2 panels 7 and 8. The tank foundation is crushed rock with a steel retaining wall and is in poor condition with heavy oil and soil buildup within the rock fill. There is light soil buildup found covering the chime. All nozzles and man ways could not be inspected for leakage due to this tank being out of service and still under repairs at this time; however, there are no signs of leakage at this time.
The roof access stair way is securely attached to the tank and is in good condition. The roof is coated and there is no evidence of corrosion or pitting. There is no evidence of leakage from the roof deck plate gasket. Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to limited access. Some sagging was noted in roof plates but does not appear to affect drainage.
Recommendations : Remove excess soil build up in rock bed, around retaining ring and on the chime and restore rock fill with clean rock. Re-coat the internal panels before putting tank in service. Re-inspect tank when repairs are completed and in service.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to have moderate scale built up from product on existing panels. Areas were scraped and cleaned on the existing panels and no evidence of corrosion found. Course 1 panels 3 through 10 were replaced due to corrosion. Roof supports are in good condition. All internal components were removes so the floor could be inspected; there was no visual evidence of corrosion or pitting found at this time.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 09/08/2016. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 05/22/2027 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken 09/09/2011.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. The external paint coating is in fair condition with light product stains and some small areas of peeling. Light surface rust is present at areas where the paint has peeled away and exposed the shell. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. Some light soil and heavy oil buildup was found in the rock ring and on the tank chime. Build-up should be removed and rock cleaned to prevent run-off water from pooling around the bottom of the tank. Small leaks were noted on several nozzle attachments on the tank possibly caused by loose attachments or failed gaskets. Tank seam gaskets are in good condition and show no signs of cracking or leakage. Electronic level gauges are used on this tank and appear to be in serviceable condition. Accuracy of these gauges was not covered in this inspection. No grounding connection was found attached to the tank.
The roof access stairway is in good condition and is secured to the tank. Tank roof inspection was not permitted at this time.
Recommendations:
Areas of coating failure and surface rusting should be cleaned and recoated to prevent corrosion. Clean soil and oil buildups from within the rock ring and tank chime to prevent run-off water from pooling around the tank. Check and repair leaking nozzles as necessary. Install a dedicated grounding strap to tank. Perform inspection on roof and roof attachments.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to be in good condition and fit for continued service. Internal shell surface was coated with 5-8 mils and the floor is coated with 14-15 mils. The internal coating is in good condition with no signs of deterioration, bubbling or other defects. No pitting or corrosion was found on internal floor and shell surfaces. The roof appears to be un-coated and is in good condition with no signs of underside corrosion. MFL inspection was completed on floor plates. MFL inspection revealed no hits and found no signs of underside corrosion of the floor. Floor UT thickness is consistent with 12-Gauge .105É?ù thickness and 10-Gauge 0.135É?ù thickness and it showed minimal wall loss. Lowest reading found was .091É?ù in plates 13 and 20.

API 653 External Inspection:
This tank was currently under construction at the time of this inspection; the tank floor, shell and roof have been completely assembled and most nozzles have been bolted to the tank. Site grading appears to be sloping towards the tank foundation and may cause runoff water to pool up around the foundation and could possibly erode soil around the foundation. Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD É?? Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 47 New Thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
All new thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 10/14/2018 based on a default corrosion rate of 2 mills per year. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 8/09/2054.
There is 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 10/15/2013.
API 570 External Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in fair condition. This piping circuit is insulated in a few isolated areas and in poor condition. The insulation jacketing is missing at several locations. The existing piping is not coated and covered with light to moderate surface rust with no visual evidence of external corrosion or pitting found at this time. In some areas of this piping circuit it is buried in the soil or covered with washed-out soil and heavy vegetation. Also appears to be unprotected and the piping that is protected has plastic wrapping in poor condition; corrosion at these locations is likely. The buried and covered piping was not excavated for inspection. The line is supported by concrete blocks and steel pipe supports and in some areas the line lacks proper supports. There are shoes attached on this piping circuit in a few section of the piping and visual look to be in sound condition. During the last thickness inspection in March of 2011 only a section of the piping circuit was inspected at this time and the last TML number used was # 57 and that were the inspection stop. The new thickness inspection will start at TML 58 and end at TML 104. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 10 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 2 piping) requirements. Certain piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Recommendations: Repair, replace or removed unnecessary and damaged insulation. Re- wrap buried piping. Excavate and inspect for soil-to-air interfaces.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID Big 10
UltraPipe Circut ID GP-B40

INSPECTION REPORT
2.39 MB
ULTRAPIPE DATA REPORT
38.6 KB
FIELD DRAWING
1.11 MB
Comments:
As of 12/04/2012 this tank has been taken out of service per Tye Hammond.
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 08/07/2013 due to low thickness readings on the roof. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 06/07/2015 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken 10/07/2011.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in poor condition. The external paint coating is failing in several areas and surface rusting is present. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. Heavy soil and vegetation buildup was found in the rock ring and built-up against the tank. Paint coating failure and surface rusting was noted along the chime where there was no soil buildup. Other areas could not be inspected due to the heavy buildup. No leaks or seam seepage was noted at any bolted joint. Tank seam gaskets are in fair condition and show signs of cracking in places. Several bolts are missing around the roof to shell joint. Nozzle N-1 is missing 1 bolt and other nozzles have insufficient threads engaged on the nuts. Manway 2 on the roof is missing nearly all bolting. The target board is in good condition and is functional.
The roof access ladder appears to be built from tubing which is not permitted by OSHA guidelines. The cage around the ladder is in good condition. Tank roof inspection was limited to visual from a distance due to limited roof access. Scattered coating failure and rusting/corrosion were noted through out the roof plates. Some roof plate sagging was noted in areas and may lead to rain water pooling on the roof of the tank. Several holes were noted on the roof around the roof to shell joint caused by through wall corrosion. Spot UT thickness readings indicate the roof has internal corrosion.
Recommendations: Remove tank from service and complete a full internal inspection to assess the condition of internal surfaces and extent of corrosion. Thoroughly inspect the roof and floor for underside corrosion. Soil and vegetation buildup in rock ring should be cleared and the chime should be inspected. Evaluate the severity of shell depressions and repair if necessary. Replace missing bolts and re-secure bolting so all threads are engaged. Recoat tank. Grade site to direct runoff around and away from tank and foundation. Replace roof access ladder with an OSHA approved ladder.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is highly recommended at the earliest convenience.
UltraPipe Unit ID HOMEBASE
UltraPipe Circuit ID -MERG SPILL TANK

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the floor .All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 01/28/2019 on the shell and 02/17/2026 on the floor. The predicted retirement date is 01/08/2022 for the shell and 09/24/2045 for the floor based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate and calculated corrosion rates. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness survey taken 02/18/2016.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The external surface on the shell and nozzles is painted and found to be in fair condition with no chipping or peeling noted. The tank foundation is crushed rock ring with steel retaining wall. The retaining wall is in good condition with some light debris lying around from the shutdown. Several leaks were found on the vertical and horizontal seams most likely caused by improper tightness of shell plate bolting. A ground connection is present and currently attached to the tank
The roof access ladder, stairway and catwalk are securely attached to the tank and are in good condition. Roof inspection was limited to a visual from the access from catwalk. Over all the roof looks to be in good condition.
Recommendations:
Check plate seams for tightness. Next inspection is due in 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank floor to be in good condition. The tank was removed from service and cleaned Prior to entry. Internal floor surface was coated and in fair condition, with light oily product stain which did not hinder inspections. No product side corrosion or pitting was visible on any internal surfaces. Most of bolting appears to be in good condition and Shows no signs of metal loss. Note some of the protective bolt caps are missing. Some bolts have broken off and were being replaced with new bolts and caps at the time of inspection. No evidence of leaks or failed gaskets was found. The sacrificial anodes were replaced. The roof is supported by external rafters connected to a center support post. Next inspection is due 02/17/2026 due to half life.

UltraPipe Circuit ID TK-30; TK-30_FLOOR

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD established procedures. 239 Thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were re-inspected at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the next inspection date cannot be determine due to 3 TMLÉ??s being below T-min and 80 caution TMLÉ??s. There are 83 caution TMLs per the current thickness survey taken on 06/23/2015.
API 570 External Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection was performed and found this piping circuit to be in fair condition. This piping circuit is insulated in a few isolated areas and in poor condition. The insulation jacketing and end cover are missing at several locations. The existing piping is not coated and covered with light to moderate surface rust with no visual evidence of external corrosion or pitting found at this time. In some areas of this piping circuit it is buried in the soil or covered with washed-out soil and heavy vegetation. Also appears to be unprotected and the piping that is protected has plastic wrapping in poor condition; corrosion at these locations is likely. The buried and covered piping was not excavated for inspection. The line is supported by concrete blocks and steel pipe supports and in some areas the line lacks proper supports. Note some alteration was made on this piping circuit since last inspection was performed back in September of 2011. Some of the TMLÉ??s have been removed because areas of the piping circuit have been altered, and new piping was installed so new base line UT thickness reading was taken and new TML location was establish. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 10 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 3 piping) requirements. Certain piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Recommendations: Repair, replace or removed unnecessary and damaged insulation. Re- wrap buried piping. Excavate and inspect for soil-to-air interfaces.

API 653 External Inspection:
Production Tank, T-101 sits on a skirt that has fire proofing. The skirt sits on a raised concrete base. The concrete base has moderate cracking located on the east side. The tank is located in a concrete retaining area (the base and walls are all concrete) the retaining area is in good condition. The bottom of the tank is coned and was viewed through an opening in the skirt, access to bottom inside skirt was denied by customer.
The shell is insulated so inspection ports were installed to complete thickness reading however visual inspection of the shell surface could not be completed. No leaks or stain areas were noted on the insulation covering. All flange connections on the shell found to be in good condition with no leaks found. The insulation on the shell is in good condition with one top panel having slight damage. Grounding was attached to the skirt at the base of the skirt. Access to the roof was denied by the customer all visuals completed from a vantage point next to the tank. The roof was not insulated and appeared to be in good condition. The PVRV was located in the center and appears to be in good condition. No leaks or stains found on the roof and the paint coating is in fair condition. Tank built in 1990. The shell material was found to be A285C, Manufactured by CBI Na-Con, Inc.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 10/23/2016. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 12/21/2066 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 10/24/2011. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. External inspection was limited to exposed portions of the shell through inspection ports. The insulation is in good condition with no areas of damage noted. Insulation sealing around nozzles and manways is in place and in good condition. Light staining was noted on insulation jacketing. The tank foundation is a concrete ring and the tank appears to be anchored to the ring. The foundation was mostly clean and shows no evidence of tank bottom leakage. The bottom to shell joint was covered by insulation and not accessible for inspection. Several flanged connections were found to have inadequate bolting; bolts are missing on nozzle N-10, insufficient thread engagements on nuts on nozzles N-6, N-7, N-8, N-9, N-10 and N-11. Some flanges have product buildup on or around the flanges and could indicate flange leakage. A grounding strap is attached to this tank.
The roof access stairway is securely attached to the tank and is in good condition. Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to limited access. Inspection of the roof was limited to visual from the manlift basket. No corrosion, pitting or holes were noted and the paint coating was in fair condition. Some rusting was noted on external rafters. No sagging was noted and there is no evidence of roof drainage issues. Tank is protected from overpressure and vacuum by a PVRV which was not accessible for up close inspection at this time.
Recommendations:
Replace missing bolting and repair/replace bolting so all nut threads are engaged. Investigate possible leakage at flanged connections and repair as necessary. Remove insulation in some areas to allow inspection of shell plates and bottom to shell joint. Complete internal inspection to assess shell wall, roof and floor condition.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.

API 653 External Inspection:
Areas of rust, corrosion and scale buildup throughout tank roof due to over 50% of the coating has failed. The roof was visually inspected from platform on the side of the tank roof access was not granted by the customer. Slight sagging on 90 side of roof no standing water was present.
The tank shell has corroded bolts throughtout shell panels, light scale and rust on 25% of the shell surface.
This is due to the failure of the paint coating over 25% of the shell walls. Rusting and paint failure was found on the course 1 to course 2 ledges. The rubber seals on bolted panels have wear and tearing, some are seeping. The sample box has a product build up internally and the coating is failing externally. Manway openings have areas of rust and scale where the paint coating has failed. Level board is out of service and the cable is missing. Some areas of the chime are covered with rock and some small vegetation is growing in the rock ring. No grounding straps found.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.
UltraPipe Unit ID HOMEBASE
UltraPipe Circuit ID T-200

API 510 External Inspection:

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be time based at 5 years. The next inspection is due 09/19/2016. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 08/04/2044 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 09/20/2011.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. The paint coating on the vessels exterior shell is in good condition. There does not appear to be any product stains, surface rust, chipping or peeling occurring on the shell or heads. The shell and heads were found to be in good condition with out any evidence of leaking, cracking or corrosion. This vessel is currently not active during this inspection. All nozzles and threaded connections to shell appear to be free of leakage, and no evidence of leakage was found on all bolted flange connections. The vessel was manufactured in 1940 by National Oil and Gas Separator. The vessel is supported by skirt which is mounted to a skid and is securely fastened to a concrete foundation. The skirt and skid appeared to in good condition with light surface rusting around the base of the skirt and on the skid. The concrete foundation located under the skid was found in good condition and did not appear to have any cracks. The vessel is grounded through the bolted connection to the skid and the skid has a ground strap attached.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.

Report(s):
{rsfiles path=""data/southwestern/dehy/api570/production_fluids/pf_112/sw-dehy_production-fluids_report_071311.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/southwestern/dehy/api570/production_fluids/pf_112/sw_pf-112_ultrapipe_071311.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/southwestern/dehy/api570/production_fluids/pf_112/sw_pf-112_field-drawing_071311.pdf""}
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 101 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established across 13 lines and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. This is the first thickness inspection of this piping circuit. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data the earliest inspection date will be 07/04/2016 on line PF-109 based on a default 2 mil per year corrosion rate. The earliest predicted retirement date in this piping circuit is 01/03/2025 on line PF-109. The next thickness inspection will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness readings taken 07/05/2011 thru 07/13/2011.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. None of the piping in this circuit is painted. Surface rusting was found on flange faces and around welds where the original factory paint was ground off during construction. Some lines in this circuit are insulated and the insulation is in good condition with a few locations where the jacketing has been crushed likely caused by personnel walking on the insulation. Some light product stains were found in some locations possibly from flange blind insertions and removals. Some valves were found with light seepage at the stems. Some wood blocks were found supporting line PF-110. The piping was found in direct contact with the soil on line PF-101 and PF-110. No bolting or misalignment issues were noted. The next visual inspection will be due in 5 years.
Recommendations:
Coat piping to protect against corrosion. Repair damaged insulation to prevent water intrusion. Repair/replace valves with leaky stems. Clear out soil and support pipe to prevent contact with the ground. Wood blocks should be replaced with proper supports with bracing to limit line movement.
UltraPipe Unit ID SW
UltraPipe Circuit ID PF-112

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell, heads and nozzles.All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 07/11/2016 based on a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 01/11/2105. There are 0 caution tml locations per the current thickness reading taken 07/12/2011.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be good condition. The vessels exterior shell is fully insulated and inspection of the shell and heads were limited to areas exposed during the thickness survey. The shell appears to be in good condition with no signs of corrosion under insulation. The insulation is in good condition and there is no damage to the sheeting or sealing. This vessel is supported by saddles welded to the shell and bolted to the exchanger below. All 3 exchangers in this group are sitting on concrete pedestals which are in good condition with no signs of cracking or spalling.
There is no dedicated ground connection for these exchangers. There is no pressure relief device protecting these exchangers from overpressure.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
Recommendations:
Install a pressure relief device. Install a dedicated ground connection.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not completed during this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.
UltraPipe Unit ID SW
UltraPipe Circuit ID E-605-BA

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell, heads, manways and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be time based at 5 years. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 02/09/2059 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate.
There is 0 caution tml location per the current thickness reading taken 08/15/2011.
?ˇ
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in fair condition. The insulation sheeting on the vessels exterior shell is in good condition. For full inspection data see inspection check list on pages 5, 6 and 7 in this report. See photos below for visual info.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this vessel to be in good condition and fit for continued service. An internal sifter tray assembly along the bottom was previously removed and the attachment welds were left in place and not ground down. 4 areas of minor corrosion measuring .030É?ù to .045É?ù were found along the old sifter tray location and were likely caused by sediment buildup on the sifter tray. 1 isolated pit was found in the shell to .060É?ù deep and 1 isolated pit was found in the east head to .040É?ù deep. Internal piping appears to be well supported and no visible defects were noted in internal supports, piping, baffles or welds.
West Chamber
Access was restricted by internal baffles, grates and piping. The lower grate was in poor condition with several large holes approximately 24É?ù to 26É?ù round and square. Several smaller holes and general grate thinning make entry beyond the area around the manway unsafe. Heavy sludge and sediment buildup was found on the bottom of the shell and made it impossible to perform a complete visual inspection. Some areas of the bottom were clean and showed no signs of corrosion or pitting. Internal piping, weld seams and baffles appear to be in good condition.
Fire Tubes
The fire tubes were removed from the Treater and hydro-blasted. The fire tubes were visually inspected and no corrosion, pitting, bulges or visible cracks were found. Magnetic particle examination was not completed at this time.
Recommendations:
Remove and replace entire lower grate. While lower grate is removed, thoroughly clean and inspect the bottom shell.
UltraPipe Unit ID FAIRFLD
UltraPipe Circuit ID
TREATER 2

API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. The insulation sheeting on the vessels exterior shell is in good condition. For full inspection data see inspection check list on pages 5, 6 and 7 in this report. See photos below for visual info.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this vessel to be in good condition and fit for continued service. Surface rusting was present through internal shell and heads. Some light corrosion was found in isolated areas and was not deep enough to be gauged. Some of the corrosion was found near an on nozzle and shell chamber welds and should be evaluated in future inspections for growth. Some isolated pitting was found with a maximum depth of .060É?ù. All internal piping appears to be properly supported and all piping, supports and baffles were in good condition.
Recommendations:
Evaluate corrosion on and around weld seams at next inspection for growth. Consider applying an internal coating to protect against corrosion. The next internal inspection will be due in 10 years per API 510.

{rsfiles path=""data/fairfield/water_plant/tanks/t-1225/2011/fairfield_t1225_report_021111.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/fairfield/water_plant/tanks/t-1225/2011/fairfield_t1225_ultrapipe_021111.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/fairfield/water_plant/tanks/t-1225/2011/fairfield_t1225_field-drawing_021111.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/fairfield/water_plant/tanks/t-1225/2011/fairfield_t1225_const_dwg_021111.pdf""}
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles. Readings were also taken on the roof and floor at the perimeter. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 05/17/2021 for the shell and 03/04/2021 for the floor. The predicted retirement date is 08/17/2026 for the shell and 03/04/2026 for the floor based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness survey taken 02/16/2016 for the shell and 03/04/2016 for the floor. Next inspection dates are governed by half-life.
API 653 External Inspection (02/16/2016):
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. The external paint coating is in good condition with areas of product stains and light corrosion/surface rusting. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The retaining wall on the north side has minor corrosion due to water present and has dirt covering gravel base in ring. Soil buildup was noted within the rock ring and covering the chime in places. Soil buildup was cleared in areas around the chime and surface rusting with light corrosion was noted. Several seams have seepage present indicating possible gasket failure or loose bolting.
The roof access stairway is securely attached to the tank. Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to limited access.
Recommendations: Soil buildup should be cleared out from the rock ring to allow for proper water run-off. Check bolting torque on shell seams and adjust as necessary to address seepage at shell plate seams.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years (02/16/2021).
API 653 Internal Inspection (03/04/2016 and 03/15/2016):
The tank was removed from service and cleaned prior to entry. Internal inspections found the tank floor to be in poor condition. Internal floor surface was found to have coating failure scattered throughout on the tank floor, with some areas having light to moderate corrosion present. Those areas will need to be re-coated to protect from any future corrosion. Plate 9,10,11,15 and 16 was found to have through wall product side corrosion and will need to repairs before going back in service. See field drawing for location. All bolting and protective caps appear to be in good condition and show no signs of metal loss. No evidence of gasket failure was found. The sacrificial anodes are in good condition. No pitting or corrosion was found on the shell plates and the paint coating is in good condition. The roof is supported by external rafters connected to a center support post. Rafters are in good condition and show no signs of damage.
Repairs were completed on after the internal inspection and a re-inspection was completed to document the repairs. All required and recommended repairs were completed.
The next internal visual inspection will be due 03/04/2021 based on the floor inspection date.
UltraPipe Unit ID FAIRFLD
UltraPipe Circuit ID T-1225; T-1225 FLOOR

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 08/25/2016. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 07/11/2026 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate.
There are 0 caution tml locations per the current thickness reading taken 08/26/2011. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be good condition. The insulation on the vessels exterior shell is in fair condition with some minor dings and some areas of insulation separation. The supports are in good condition with some coating chipping and light surface rust. The foundation is concrete pedestals and is in good condition with minor chipping and cracking. Vessel anchor bolting is secure. A ground strap is attached to the support and is secure. The vessel is protected from overpressure by a PSV attached to nozzle N-5 and set at 110 PSI which is below the data plate MAWP of 125 PSI. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
Recommendations:
Repair damage to insulation to prevent water intrusion. Consider remove small sections of insulation to perform a corrosion under insulation (CUI) examination. Also consider performing Positive Material Identification (PMI) and Brinnel Hardness Testing to confirm the assumed material type.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this vessel to be in good condition. Some pitting was found in the shell and the deepest pit was .125É?ù deep and is within acceptable limits. Internal piping, baffles and sifter boxes were in good condition. All internal weld seams were in good condition with no signs of corrosion or pitting on weld surfaces or within HAZ. The next internal inspection will be in 7 years due to a remaining life of 14 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID PAN FEE
UltraPipe Circuit ID
V-230

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on 10/17/11.
API 510 External Inspection:
This inspection has found the equipment to be in fair condition. The supports were in good condition and the anchor bolts are secure. The shell, south head, support saddles and nozzles all have light to moderate surface rust. The insulation interface has minor C.U.I and surface rust in punctured and damaged areas of insulation. The access-way and gauges are in good condition.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
During this internal inspection all previous pitting was to be repaired by weld overlay, all repairs performed were in good condition. During the inspection the vesselÉ??s sand pan was not removed or cleaned and large amounts of buildup was still present which made it difficult to perform an adequate inspection of the bottom section of the vesselÉ??s shell. No major pitting or corrosion was found during the inspection, only one small area had minor pitting that measured 1/16É?ù in depth which is acceptable. The sides and top of the vessel were in good condition and were free from any pitting and major corrosion. The fire tube support rack was in good condition as well, with no beams twisted or any broken welds or beams seen.
Recommendations :
É?õ Remove sand pan and clean so an adequate inspection can be performed on the bottom section of the shell

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection :
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 10 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 10/08/2017 based on a 2 mil per year corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 01/08/2026.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 01/09/2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. Circuit was not painted and not insulated. The coating on the circuit is the manufactures coating. There is light surface rust throughout the circuit. There was no corrosion or pitting noted throughout the pipe line. There is no vegetation built up as the pipe lines are not sitting directly on the ground and are not buried anywhere.
