{rsfiles path=""data/homebase/api653/t_530/2012/homebase_t-erst-1_report_011312.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/homebase/api653/t_530/2012/homebase_t-erst-1_ultrapipe_011312.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/homebase/api653/t_530/2012/homebase_t-erst-1_field-drawings_011312.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/homebase/api653/t_530/2012/homebase_t-erst-1_vac-test-report_011312.pdf""}
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 07/28/2019. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 11/29/2033 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 07/28/2014. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. This tank external shell and head is 100% insulated and found to be in fair condition. The tank foundation is a crushed rock with a steel retaining wall. The retaining wall is below grade level in one area and could not be inspected. Soil buildup was noted within the rock ring and covering the chime in places. Soil buildup was cleared in areas around the chime and surface rusting was note.
The roof access ladder is securely attached to the tank and the paint coating is in fair condition with surface rusting present. Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to limited access. No excessive sagging was noted.
Recommendations: Soil buildup should be cleared out from the rock ring. The rock ring retaining wall should be repaired as needed.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Last internal inspection was 12/2012
UltraPipe Unit ID HOMEBASE
UltraPipe Circuit ID
T-530

Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. Seven thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 01/09/2017 based on a 2 mil per year corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 01/10/2023.
There are 0 caution TML‚Äôs per the current thickness reading taken on 01/10/2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found the piping circuit to be in good condition. Circuit was not painted and not insulated. The coating on the circuit is the manufactures coating. There is light surface rust throughout the circuit. There was no corrosion or pitting noted throughout the pipe line. There is no vegetation built up as the pipe lines are not sitting directly on the ground and are not buried anywhere. There was no pressure or temperate gauge installed at time of inspection.
The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.

Comments: \t\t\t\t
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey: \t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 01/04/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 04/23/2029 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 01/05/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.\t\t\t\t
\t\t\t\t\t
\t\t\t\t\t
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The external paint coating is in fair condition with areas of product stains and light corrosion/surface rusting. The tank foundation is crushed rock with a steel retaining wall and it is in poor condition. The crushed rock retaining ring is caved-in in places around the tank and corrosion of the ring wall is present. The foundation rock fill is severely degraded with several cavities under the tank shell. Dirt buildup was found within the rock ring. There is scale and corrosion around the #2 panel bolting area. Sample box has product build up and there are two sample line connections that are leaking. The inspection opening has product by and around it, product is also going under the bottom of the tank floor as well as scale, corrosion and buildup. Nozzle #15 has light paint blistering around connection to the tank shell. There is a 6É?ù X 6É?ù patch on the bottom of panel #15, the tank bottom from the ring sunk down approximately 6É?ù. There is corrosion and scale on the bottom panels of the tank. There are cavities under the tank on the 180?¯ and 270?¯ side.\t\t\t\t\t
The stair platform is missing bolts and is not connected to the roof. Nozzles have light corrosion and manways have light rust. There is scale and corrosion found throughout the entire roof and 4 patches were found. No holes were visible at this time. There is also sagging on the roof from 180?¯ to 270?¯, possibly from internal rafter failure.
\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
Recommendations: Repair damaged rock ring wall and refill rock foundation to close any cavities. Remove soil buildup from foundation. Areas of coating failure should be cleaned and recoated. Repair/replace leaking sample line connections. Perform internal inspection at earliest convenience and assess condition of floor.\t\t\t\t\t
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.\t\t\t\t\t
\t\t\t\t\t
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
UltraPipe Unit ID HOMEBASE
UltraPipe Circuit ID T-100

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell only.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 01/29/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 03/06/2045 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 01/30/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
Tank is under construction, the roof and nozzles are not installed yet. Foundation was replaced prior to new tank construction. The tank shell is free from any blisters or bulging. Shell bolting appears to be in good condition and accessible bolting is secure. The tank coating is new and there are no visible defects. The tank is not yet grounded but grounding wires are in place around foundation. The tank foundation is fitted with a leak detection system. Containment dike is a cinder block wall around five tanks and is in poor condition. Large cracks and erosion was found in several locations. Dike drains are in poor condition and do not appear serviceable.
Recommendations: Follow-up inspection once tank construction is complete. Repair cracks and holes in cinder block wall. Test and repair dike drains as necessary.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. The next internal visual inspection will be time based at 10 years.

INSPECTION REPORT

NG-100 ULTRAPIPE DATA REPORT
28.76 KB
NG-101 ULTRAPIPE DATA REPORT
50.71 KB
FIELD DRAWING
448.64 KB
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD É?? Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 59 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established across 2 circuits and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data, the next inspection will be 02/01/2017 based on a minimum 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 12/27/2040 on circuit NG-100. The next thickness survey is time based at 5 years.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 02/02/2012.
API 510 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. This inspection is limited to accessible above ground sections. This line starts at the Mohave Gas Pipeline station approximately 2.5 miles south of the Poso Creek lease. There is a PIG launcher located at the south metering/regulating station just outside of the Mohave Gas Station. The line travels north underground from this location, crosses under Poso Creek waterway and comes above ground approximately ?¨ mile south of the Poso Creek Lease to cross a small stream before going back underground. A PIG receiver is located at the Poso Creek lease where the line comes above ground and goes through additional regulators prior to tying-in to existing lease gas piping. There are 2 pressure drops in this line; the first pressure drop is at the South Metering Station. The pressure was reduced from 800 PSI to 400 PSI at this station. The second pressure drop is located at the Poso Creek metering station and the pressure reduces from 400 PSI to 200 PSI before tying into existing lease piping. A PSV was located on the 200 PSI side of this line and set at 250PSI. Condensation was found on the piping around the first pressure drop. The condensation was pooling at the pipe to support interfaces and may lead to corrosion issues in the future and should be monitored.
Soil was eroding below the supports of piping running between the Mohave Station and the Berry South Metering Station and the piping was not in contact with the supports in this area. Other above ground piping was found to be sufficiently supported and anchored. Soil-to-air interfaces were found to be well wrapped and no damage to the wrapping was noted. This line is equipped with cathodic protection for underground stretches and is electrically isolated with insulated bolting at the first flange prior to going underground and first flange above ground. Underground portions are setup for Pigging and all visible direction changes were achieved by long radius bends.
All piping in this circuit is considered Class 1 due to crossing active waterways. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years. No jurisdictional considerations have been made in regards to extent of inspection or the next inspection date.
UltraPipe Unit ID POSO
UltraPipe Circuit ID
NG-100
NG-101
" "

X-Ray established procedures. Forty thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established over two circuits and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 02/01/2017 based on a 2 mil per year corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 02/01/2029. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 02/02/2012. The next thickness inspection will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 510 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. This piping circuit was installed on a H beam steel skid and steel support. The steel skid was not coated and it was found to have light surface rust throughout. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.

Report(s):
{rsfiles path=""data/pan_fee/field/api570/flow_lines/well_36r_fl/2012/panfee_field_well_36r_fl_report_020912.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/pan_fee/field/api570/flow_lines/well_36r_fl/2012/panfee_field_well_36r_fl_ultrapipe_020912.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/pan_fee/field/api570/flow_lines/well_36r_fl/2012/panfee_field_well_36r_fl_field_drawing_020912.pdf""}
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. Thirty Five thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 02/08/2022 based on a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 08/10/2068. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 02/09/2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. Piping circuit is found to have 1 leak and another location with some residue. The leak is located at the bottom threads of a vertical union on the gas piping directly off the casing and some residue was found on the 1‚Äù valve plug downstream of the trombone. See field drawing for leak locations. Multiple areas of movement were found at the trombone, TML‚Äôs 2, 9-10, 14-15, 16-17 & 27-28. The movement found at expansion loops is due to the piping is operating at 430¬∞F and is under thermal expansion causing the support shoes to lift off pipe support. Recommend additional supports at TML locations 2, 16 & 17. Most of the insulation seals are in fair condition with exception of an area of insulation is cut out for a pipe running across the top with no seals and the pipe supports have no seals. Pipe wrap where piping goes under roadways is intact and in good condition. Some small dents are found on the insulation. Surface rust is found on the support shoes.
Recommendations:
Repair leaking union and determine if residue found on 1‚Äù valve plug is from a leak and repair as necessary. Follow-up inspection will be required once repairs have been completed.
UltraPipe Unit ID PAN FEE
UltraPipe Circuit ID WELL_36R_FL

The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 02/09/2059. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 02/09/2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. Most of the insulation seals are in fair condition with exception of an area of insulation is cut out for a pipe running across the top with no seals and the pipe supports have no seals. Pipe wrap where piping goes under roadways is intact and in good condition. Some small dents are found on the insulation. Surface rust is found on the support shoes. The well has D-175 written with weld metal on the casing. Some support shoes are not resting on pipe supports mainly on thermal expansion loops. Next inspection will be time based at 10 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID PAN FEE
UltraPipe Circuit ID WELL_I-75_FL

API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. Three leaks were found around threaded fittings. A 2‚Äù hammer union between TML 1 & 2, 1‚Äù valve plug and a check valve upstream of TML 1 are seeping oil onto the ground and nearby piping. See field drawing for leak locations. A few missing seals were found at A 1‚Äù valve near the Pan Fee Header 2 location and all support locations have open seals. Pipe wrap where piping goes under roadways is intact and in good condition. Some small dents are found on the insulation. Surface rust is found on the support shoes. Recommendations:

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 7 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 01/09/2017 based on 2 mils per year. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 01/10/2031.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 03-08-2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. Piping circuit is found out of service and disconnected at threaded hammer union near pumping unit. Operating pressure and temperature are unavailable at this time. Some debris was found on pipe and light surface rust was found at welds and heat affected zones. The inspector recommends that once the circuit is put into service a recheck of conditions be re-inspected. Two locations were found touching nearby piping & insulation sheeting. One near CML 2 and the other at CML 5. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 10 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 2 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID 21Z
UltraPipe Circuit ID
WELL-O13_CVR

The next inspection will be time based at 10 years.

Equipment ID: T-10

Last: 03/07/2012
Next: 03/28/2017
Inspector: James Reese
Report(s):
INSPECTION REPORT
3.13 MB
ULTRAPIPE DATA REPORT
84.86 KB
FIELD DRAWING
1.14 MB
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 03/07/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 01/17/2028 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 03/07/2012.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. The external paint coating is in good condition with a few areas of light chipping found. The shell plates are free of any bulging, peeking, and banding and the shell joints appear to be free of any leaks. No loose bolting was found and all joint gaskets were in good condition. Product seepage was noted at the sample connections, nozzle N-4 and nozzle N-10 likely caused by failed gaskets. The tank foundation is in poor condition; the crushed rock bed is filled with soil and oil buildup and there is a thin oil buildup on the chime in some places. The rock bed is completely covered by soil run-off in some places. The steel retaining wall has a few minor dents. It appears at one point, the entire internal area of the containment dike was flooded approximately 12-16É?ù judging from the water/oil lines on the shell of this tank and the neighboring tank. The surrounding grade had areas of heavy oil buildup which poses a fire hazard for the tank and a slipping hazard for workers. Several drainage ditches were carved in the grade to direct run-off and leaks away from the tank to nearby drains.
The roof access stairway is in good condition. The roof is in good condition and shows no signs of sagging or inadequate drainage.
The containment dike is in good condition; however, the dike drains appear to be in non-serviceable condition.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to be in good condition. Pitting and holes were found in several locations across the floor and were filled and patched prior to this inspection. No remaining pitting or holes were found during this inspection. Areas of pitting that were not patched were filled in with epoxy to prevent corrosion. The floor encapsulated nuts were in good condition and show no signs of deterioration. The shell surfaces were in good condition and free of any pitting or corrosion. The bolt heads were in good condition and show no signs of metal loss. The roof support and roof plates were in good condition and show no signs of deformation or corrosion. The sacrificial anodes were in poor condition and several fell off during initial cleaning. The anodes were scheduled to be replaced but were not replaced at the time of this inspection. The next internal inspection will be time based at 15 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID PLAC
UltraPipe Circuit ID
T-10

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. Twenty Seven thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 02/08/2022 based on a 2 mil per year corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 02/09/2032. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 02/09/2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. No leaks were found on this circuit. Some oil debris was found on piping and insulation sheeting beneath stuffing box. Most of the insulation seals are in fair condition with exception of areas around pipe supports, (2) sections of insulation sheeting are missing approximately 3‚Äô and (2) locations which appear to be burn through holes. Paint can be seen in these (2) cut out sections of insulation and the paint appears to be fading and flaking. Surface rust is appearing in these areas. Pipe wrap is intact and in good condition. Some small dents are found on the insulation along with (2) locations where the insulation is severely distorted on the top sections. One location is found between TML 22 & 23 and the other is found west of the Pan Fee Header 2. Both locations appear to have a lot of traffic across insulation and it is recommended to construct a catwalk for each location to prevent further insulation sheeting destruction. South of TML 17, an area of insulation is separating and may require more screws to hold in place. Support shoes contain moderate surface rust and (2) expansion loops support are experiencing thermal expansion causing support shoes to lift off pipe supports. The well is found in service but no gauges were found to determine pressure or temperature. The next inspection will be time based at 10 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID PAN FEE
UltraPipe Circuit ID
FL-106

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 11 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. Olympus 38 DL Plus with a D-791 RM search unit in standard mode, 3 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 04/18/2017 based on a 2 mil per year corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 10/18/2024.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 04/18/2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. The valves are open but the K.O. is out of service. Light surface rust was found at welds & heat affected zones. All bolting was secure and gaskets are inserted. Piping is supported by (2) flanged connections. One off CVR-1000 and the other is on K.O. 211. The support is in good condition. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 5 year thickness inspection interval per API (class _ piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID 21Z
UltraPipe Circuit ID
CVR-300

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial X-Ray established procedures. 9 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 07/19/2017 based on a 2 mil per year corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 10/19/2022.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 04/19/2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. Piping circuit is found in service and no leaks were found. Some debris was found on pipe and light surface rust was found at welds, heat affected zones & supports. Wood 2‚Äùx4‚Äù support is used between CML 3 & 4 as support. This will need to be replaced. Also at location CML 7 may require additional support. The pipe is also resting against the metal grating upstream of CML 7. The pipe may need to be centered in the grating. The pipe movement is causing the grating to rub the pipe in the areas of contact. No movement was found at this time but there is evidence of markings on the pipe at that location from the grating. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 10 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 2 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID 21Z
UltraPipe Circuit ID
WELL_K-15_CVR

Comments:
Note 08/27/2012: This tank has been taken out of service in July 2012 per Tye Hammond.
?ˇ
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 04/20/2017 and with a predicted retirement date of 05/02/2036, based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 04/20/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
?ˇ
API 653 External Inspection
External inspection found this tank to be in poor condition. The external insulation is in fair condition on shell with areas of product stains. Sealing around nozzles and insulation penetrations was in fair condition in some places and not present in other ares. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The retaining wall is in fair condition. Heavy soil buildup was noted within the rock ring and chime in areas and completely covers the foundation in some areas. Soil buildup was cleared in areas around the chime and light surface rust with light corrosion was noted. No grounding connection was found.
The roof access stairway is securely attached to the tank and the paint coating is in poor condition with surface rusting present. Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to limited access and insulated roof.?ˇ External insulation on the roof was also found to be in poor condition with gaps and holes cut around nozzles. Insulation sheeting on the roof is mostly gone. There is a large area of sagging present, most likely due to internal rafter failure.
Recommendations: Clean soil and vegetation buildups from rock ring and restore rock fill. Clear unnecessary flamable debris from around the tank. Remove small areas (12É?ùx12É?ù) in several locations around shell and on roof to inspect for corrosion under insulation (CUI). Replace missing target board and indicator. Repair leaking valves. Consider reinsulation tank. Consider cleaning and recoating access platform. Consider servicing and testing dike drains. Internal inspection is HIGHLY recommended as soon as possible due to sagging roof.
?ˇ
API 653 Internal Inspection
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is HIGHLY recommended at the next planned shutdown.

UltraPipe Circuit ID

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 04/20/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 05/18/2029 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 04/20/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
?ˇ
API 653 External Inspection
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The external insulation is in fair condition with areas of product stains. The shell insulation has some loose bands. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall and is in fair condition. Heavy soil buildup was noted within the rock ring and covering the chime in areas. Soil buildup was cleared in areas around the chime and surface rusting with light corrosion was noted. The level indicator and target board are in good condition but the cable is not attached to the indicator rendering the level indicator inoperative. Inspection of shell surfaces could not be conducted due to the insulation.
The roof access stairway paint coating is in poor condition with surface rusting present. With limited access to the roof, visual inspection was preformed from a distance. The roof insulation appears to be intact and in fair condition with no noticeable sagging. Some small breaks in the insulation were noted and these breaks could allow moisture to enter and become trapped between the roof deck and insulation.
Recommendations: Soil buildup should be cleaned out from the rock ring and the rock fill should be restored. Clear out flamables from around the tank such as wooden pallets and vegetation. Grade side around tank to divert runoff water around foundation. Consider installing shoring to prevent soil errosion from nearby hillside from washing out onto tank foundation. Clean and recoat roof access stairway. Replace damaged insulation and repair leaking valves. Repair level indicator cable. Consider removing small sections (12É?ùx12É?ù) of insulation in several locations around the shell and on the roof to access the shell and roof condition and determin the need for further inspection. Internal inspection is highly recommended as soon as possible.
?ˇ
API 653 Internal Inspection
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.

2016 INSPECTION DATA:
{rsfiles path=""data/fairfield/dehy/api653/t111/2016/fairfield-dehy_t-111_report_050516.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/fairfield/dehy/api653/t111/2016/fairfield-dehy_t-111_ultrapipe_050516.pdf""}

2011 INSPECTION DATA:
{rsfiles path=""data/fairfield/dehy/api653/t111/2011/fairfield-dehy_t-111_report_111611.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/fairfield/dehy/api653/t111/2011/fairfield-dehy_t-111_ultrapipe_111611.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/fairfield/dehy/api653/t111/2011/fairfield-dehy_t-111_fielddrawing_111611.pdf""}
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell, floor, and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 05/05/2021 for the shell and 08/05/2019 for the floor. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 05/06/2026 for the shell and 11/04/2022 for the floor based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 05/05/2016.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. The foundation is in poor condition with heavy soil and oil buildup throughout. The site grading around the tank directs water flow towards the north side of the tank and is the likely cause of soil buildup within the rock foundation. The rock fill has eroded away on the south west side of the tank causing a cavity under the bottom and has resulted in the shell settling at this location. Shell plate gaskets were found cracked but no shell plate leaks were noted. One dedicated grounding connection was found attached to this tank.
There is no roof acces platform and a limited inspection was conducted from surrounding hills. No signs of sagging or drainage issues were noted. Attached piping appears to be properly supported. Minor rust stains are present likely from the unpainted nozzle bolting and blind plates. No visible damage was noted on the attached PVRV.
Recommendations: Clean soil and oil buildup from foundation and restore rock fill. Fill in cavities under tank. Grade surrounding area to direct drainage water and soil erosion away from the tank foundation. Monitor plate gaskets for leakage. Service PVRV.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. Coating chipping and blistering areas were found throughout on the floor. Blistering on the bottom half of the manway ID. 1 bolt was found missing on the floor. 2 anodes were found on the West and East sides of the tank. Internal piping and supports are in good condition. No pitting or corrosion was found on internal tank surfaces. The roof support structure appears to be in good condition and no twisted or damage rafters can be seen. Internal plate gaskets are in good condition.
Recommendations: Replace missing floor bolt. Consider replacing floor bolting with rubber-encapsulated nuts to prevent bolting corrosion in the future. Spot repair coating chips and repair damaged coating on north manway.
Update 05/16/2016:
Floor Plate 1 was replaced due to excessive corrosion in the bolt row. Missing and corroded bolting was replaced. Coating was patched where damaged. Tank is good to return to service.
UltraPipe Unit ID FAIRFLD
UltraPipe Circuit ID
T-111 / T-111 FLOOR

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 11/09/2016. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 06/16/2031 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 11/10/2011.
API 653 External Inspection
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. The crushed rock foundation is in good condition with very little soil build up in isolated areas. No vegetation or other flamables were found around the tank. The shell and roof are 100% insulated so the external condition could not be inspected. The insulation is in fair condition with several areas noted where the banding has come loose and is hanging down. This causes gaps in the insulation which could allow water intrusion. A dedicated grounding connection was found attached to this tank.
The roof access stairway was in good condition with no signs of deterioration noted. Roof access was not permited at the time of this inspection.
Recommendations: Repair loose insulation bands. Remove small sections (12É?ùx12É?ù squares) of insulation in several areas around the shell paying close attention to the bottom to shell joint to inspect for corrosion under insulation and to determin the need for more insulation removal.
API 510 Internal Inspection
Internal inspection found this tank to be in good condition. The floor, shell and roof are free of any visible corrosion, pitting or holes. Internal piping, baffles and appertenances were in good condition with no signs of degredation noted. Floor thickness was consistent with 10 gauge nominal wall. All bolt heads were free of any visible signs of corrosion and the floor captive nuts were in good condition. No evidence of shell, roof or floor mechanical damage was noted during the inspection. No evidence of leaks were found.

INSPECTION REPORT
1.62 MB
ULTRAPIPE DATA REPORT
66.74 KB
FIELD DRAWINGS
166.4 KB
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed internally on the floor and externally on the shell. The bolted tank is still under construction no thickness data can be recorded on roof pates or nozzles due to uncompleted construction. A-Scan readings were performed using an Olympus 38 DL Plus with a D-790-SM search unit utilizing echo-echo mode to receive true wall readings through paint. During the internal inspection, data received from A-scan UT crew found that each location on the floor with a support found readings to be 0.050É?ù thicker than other areas without a support. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be in 03/21/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 10/15/2044 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 03/21/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection the new bolted tank is currently still under construction and is empty and out of service at this time. There are no nozzles or roof plates installed yet. Only rafters and supports are in place at this time. The external paint coating is in good condition. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The retaining wall is in sound condition and secure. No soil buildup was found around the chime. All vertical & horizontal bolted seams were in good condition. (2) Bolts shell bolts were found loose located on the first course at approximately 120?¯. Seam gaskets show no signs of deterioration and cracking. The roof rafters and support is fully painted and is in sound condition. No access-ways or ground cables have been attached yet.
Recommendations:
A re-check of the inspection should be completed once tank is fully constructed and is put into service.
Install ground cable, tighten the (2) loose nuts on first course @ 120?¯.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection has found the tank to be fit for service and in good condition. This tank is new, empty and not fully constructed. Some edge settlement was found starting approximately 3É?? measured inward from the shell to floor joint. The settlement ranges from 1É?ù to 1.625É?ù. This settlement is located all around the perimeter of the tank. All floor plate bolted seams are in good condition. Some areas found near the critical zone to have top side nuts missing near the wall. No corrosion can be noted at this time due to the amount paint protecting all surfaces inside the tank. Good paint was found on shells, floor, roof support beam, rafters, separator wall & separator wall supports. Some separator wall supports gusset bolts were loose. The roof support and separator wall supports are intact and structurally sound. The re-pad beneath all the supports was found welded to the plates.
Recommendations:
A re-check of the inspection should be completed after the tank has been in service.
UltraPipe Unit ID POSO
UltraPipe Circuit ID
22K BBL ST

{rsfiles path=""data/21z/api570/cvr_lines/cvr-201/2012/21z_cvr-201_ultrapipe_042412.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/21z/api570/cvr_lines/cvr-201/2012/21z_cvr-201_fielddrawing_042412.pdf""}
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. Olympus 38 DL Plus with a D-791 RM search unit in standard mode, 45 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. 3 external erosion areas were found on the 6‚Äù. Ultrasonic thickness readings were performed in these areas to locate the remaining wall. 2 of 3 areas were approximately 0.216‚Äù in which the surrounding good areas were ~ 0.278‚Äù and the third has approximately 0.140‚Äù remaining wall and nearest area of good pipe read 0.270‚Äù. A-Scan was also performed on a 2‚Äù and a 6‚Äù dead leg.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 4/24/2017 based on a default corrosion rate of 2 mills per year. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 11/15/2043.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 04/24/2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in poor condition but is acceptable to continue service. Piping circuit is found in service. Moderate external pitting was found ranging from 0.005‚Äù to 0.110‚Äù deep and the external pitting is only located on sections between CMLs 19-20 and on the dead leg CMLs 37-44. Light scale was found in random locations where soil is touching the pipe and surface rust was found on 100% of the line. All bolting contained surface rust and was secure and gaskets are inserted. The header was found fully supported by concrete sleepers and pipe racks. No vibration was found but a leak was found near CML 4 at road crossing. Some oil residue was present inside the culvert and had dripped onto the soil. The oil was not fresh but it was apparent that it was leaking from this line somewhere inside the road crossing culvert. Oil was also found leaking from the 6‚Äù gate valve on the 6‚Äù dead leg near CML 45. Some areas were covered with dirt. These areas need to be either wrapped or have the soil removed from the pipe so that there is clearance of any water that may corrode the pipe at these locations which are: CML 5, in between wells B1, B2 & B3 2‚Äù CVR lines, CML 16 & CML 35-36 both sides of road crossing culverts. Areas of dirt were removed for evaluation of the material and light scale and surface rust was present at these locations. Centralizers were not used inside road crossing culverts. The pipe is resting on the bottom side of the 2 road crossings culverts. Centralizers should be used to elevate the pipe to keep standing water from accelerating the external corrosion. Near CML 36 the pipe was found touching a pipe support and causing friction and wear marks. If the pipe should vibrate in the future this will cause additional stresses in this location. A 2‚Äù and a 6‚Äù dead leg was found connected to this circuit. The 2‚Äù was in good condition, the 6‚Äù had external pitting 0.005‚Äù-0.080‚Äù deep. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 5 year thickness inspection interval per API (class _ piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID 21Z
UltraPipe Circuit ID
CVR-201

All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 5/02/2017 based on a 2 mill a year default corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 12/07/2052.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 5/02/2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in fair condition. This piping circuit was found to have shoes off supports on the east and west run coming from the header at north east end of piping. A piping support is missing and there is excessive overhung from this pipe support missing. The insulation was found to be loose and damaged in the area were shoes was off supports for this piping. No leakage found at the time of inspection on this piping circuit. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 5 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 2 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
RECOMMENDATION: Do more investigatetion on this piping circuit to see why piping and shoes are off pipe support, check with an engineer before repair are made.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.

\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
Field: HILLSIDE
Location: SMWSS
Equipment ID: T-10367
Inspection Dates: \t\t\t\t
Last: 05/31/2012\t\t\t\t
Next: N/A - Out of Service\t\t\t
Inspector: Ronnie Harleston
Report(s): \t\t\t\t
INSPECTION REPORT ( 2 MB)\t\t\t\t
ULTRAPIPE DATA REPORT ( 63 kB)\t\t\t\t
FIELD DRAWING ( 745 kB)\t\t\t
Comments: \t\t\t\t
Note 08/27/2012: This tank has been taken out of service in July 2012 per Tye Hammond.\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
\t\t\t\t
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell, nozzles and roof.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 05/30/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate is 05/30/2031. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 05/31/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.\t\t\t\t
API 653 External Inspection
External inspection of the shell found this tank to be in fair condition. The external paint coating is in fair condition with areas of product stains and light surface rusting. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The retaining wall was found to be in fair condition. Soil buildup was noted within the rock ring and covering the chime in places. Soil buildup was cleared in areas around the chime and light surface rust was found. Several vertical seam leaks were noted possibly caused by loose bolting or failed gaskets. Seam gaskets show signs of deterioration and cracking. A 2É?ù threaded pipe needs additional support near the manway. Dimpling is occurring on the shell at this location. The roof access-way is securely attached to the tank and the paint coating is in poor condition with surface rust present. External inspection of the roof was found in poor condition as seen from the access-way. Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to the amount of oil debris found and excess sagging. Rain water will not drain from roof and will remain stagnant till evaporation occurs.
Recommendations: Soil buildup and debris should be cleared out from the rock ring. Areas of coating failure should be cleaned and recoated. Replace leaking plate gaskets and check bolting torque as necessary. Replace missing target board and indicator. Perform internal inspection at earliest convenience.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.\t\t\t\t
\t\t\t\t
API 653 Internal Inspection \t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended as soon as possible.\t\t\t
UltraPipe Unit ID HILLSIDE
UltraPipe Circuit ID \t\t\t\t
T-10367\t\t\t

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 38 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 03/02/2022 based on a 2 mil per year corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 09/01/2063.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 03/02/2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. Piping is currently experiencing thermal expansion on all expansion loops causing all top shoe supports to have lift-off from pipe support. This is due to the 460¬∞F 920PSI steam injection into well. One particular location at CML 31, the support shoe has broken the ears of the pipe support bracket. See photos below. (2) Areas of piping are missing a form of support. One is missing a sleeper concrete support at CML location 9 and the other location CML 14 has shoe in place but never was attached. The insulation of the line is not completed leaving open seals for rain and debris. Some small dents are found on the insulation. Surface rust is found on the support shoes. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 5 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 3 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 10 years.

Last: 06/26/2012
Next: 06/26/2017
Inspector: Ronnie Harleston
Report(s):
{rsfiles path=""data/homebase/dehy/api510/air_receiver/2012/homebase_air-reciever_report_062612.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/homebase/dehy/api510/air_receiver/2012/homebase_air-reciever_ultrapipe_062612.pdf""}
{rsfiles path=""data/homebase/dehy/api510/air_receiver/2012/homebase_air-reciever_field-drawing_062612.pdf""}
Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on shell and head, nozzles for corrosion monitoring purposes. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 06/26/2017. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 12/16/2022 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution tml locations per the current thickness reading taken 06/26/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 External Inspection:
External inspection found the vessel to be good condition. The coating on this vessels exterior shell and head is in fair condition. This vessel is supported by 3 legs mounted on a concrete pad and found to be in good condition. All flanges and attach piping on this vessel the bolting is securely fastened. There is no visible evidence of leakage or external corrosion found on this vessel. No dents, bulges or deformations were found in exterior surfaces. The next visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
Recommendations: Install a vent pipe on the PSV discharge side. Consider recoating the vessel exterior.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Due to size limitations, vessel entry is not possible. An on-stream inspection was conducted in lieu of internal inspection as allowed by API 510. Additional CML points were established on the shell and heads and Ultrasonic A-Scan Grids were scanned at random locations on the heads and shell. These additional inspections revealed no signs of internal corrosion or pitting. Some thinning in the crown of both heads was noted and due to the nature of the thinning, it is most likely to have been caused by the fabrication of the heads rather than corrosion. It is still recommended the heads be re-evaluated at the next interval for corrosion. See the A-Scan Grid reader sheet on page 10 for scan details.
UltraPipe Unit ID HOMEBASE
UltraPipe Circuit ID
AIR RECEIVER

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 6 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 03/21/2017 based on a 2 mil per year corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 03/21/2029.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 03-14-2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. Piping circuit is found out of service and disconnected at threaded hammer union near pumping unit. Operating pressure and temperature are unavailable at this time. Light surface rust was found at welds and heat affected zones. The inspector recommends that once the circuit is put into service a recheck of conditions be re-inspected. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 5 year thickness inspection interval per API (class _ piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID 21Z
UltraPipe Circuit ID WELL-H15_CVR

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD established procedures. 8 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 05/23/2020. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 02/22/2024 based on calculated corrosion rates and a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 08/23/2016.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. Line is not coated. Line has area where it has fallen off the supports and is hanging. Line has vegetation around it in 2 sections of piping circuit. Flanges and bolts are in good condition with no evidence of leaks. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 10 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 2 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
Recommendations: Set line back on supports and bracket it down to keep it from sliding off. Remove vegetation from piping circuit.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 5 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID 21Z
UltraPipe Circuit ID WELL_B-2_CVR

Comments:

X-Ray established procedures. 7 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations. The circuit consists of 2É?ù & 3É?ù schedule 160, 1500# flanges.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 04/04/2022 based on a default 2 mill corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 10/05/2115.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 04/04/12.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in good condition. The line was found completely insulated and securely supported. The insulation and seals are in good condition. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 10 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 3 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the floor. 15 out of 21 floor panels were found to have thickness readings at or below t-min of .100É?ù. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date cannot be determined at this time due to thickness readings below T-min. There are 43 caution TML locations per the current thickness survey taken 01/22/2013.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection visual was not requested at this time.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to be in poor condition. The tank was removed from service and the floor and lower portion of the shell were cleaned prior to entry. The heating piping was left in the tank during the inspection. The coating on the floor is chipping and peeling in areas with light to moderate surface rust present in some locations. No visual sign of top side corrosion or pitting found; however there is a hole in panel 18. The hole appears to have caused by soil side corrosion. Floor joints and bolting were covered in a thick epoxy like coating so the condition of the seams and the bolts could not be determined. The internal roof supports are in good condition with no visible signs of corrosion. 5 holes were found in the roof but up-close inspection to determine the cause was not possible due to limited access.
Recommendations: Replace entire floor with 10 gauge .135É?ù panels to provide adequate corrosion allowance. During floor replacement, remove oil and soil buildup from the entire foundation below the floor and replace the foundation with a clean rock fill. Provide access to inspect and UT the roof to determine the cause of the holes and the overall condition of the roof. Consider recoating tank internals.
UltraPipe Unit ID POSO
UltraPipe Circuit ID TANK_20S284

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the floor. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 01/31/2018. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 04/21/2030 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 01/31/2013.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection visual was not requested at this time.
The roof access stair way is securely attached to the tank and constructed out of galvanized steel and found to be covered with crude oil on the steps and hand rail. The roof is not coated and there is no evidence of corrosion or pitting visible. Oil was found seeping from the tank roof to shell seam indicating possible gasket failure. Up-close inspection of the tank roof surface was not completed due to limited access.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. This tank was removed from service and cleaned prior to entry. The heating coils were left in the tank during the inspection and were in good condition. The coating on the floor is blistering and peeling in some areas and no visual sign of corrosion or pitting was found. No holes were found in the floor, shell or roof and no evidence of leakage was found. Product buildup was still present on most of the shell and several areas were cleaned and revealed no signs of corrosion or pitting. The roof and internal supports are covered in rusting but no visible signs of corrosion could be seen. The roof was not accessible for up-close inspection.
UltraPipe Unit ID POSO
UltraPipe Circuit ID TANK_20S283

{rsfiles path=""data/severini/dehy/api510/v_401/2012/severini_v401_report_060812.pdf""}

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed previously on shell and nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 06/08/2012. The predicted retirement date of the vessel is 12/20/2057 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate.
There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 External Inspection
External inspection found the vessel to be good condition. The equipment was found fully insulated therefore only random areas could be inspected through each thickness location porthole. The data plate is in good condition and is legible. The saddles are in good condition. Two anchor bolts were found unsecure and loose. One on each saddle. Insulation is in good condition. Some seals are in good condition and others are failing. No temperature or pressure gauge was found installed on vessel. Nozzles were found in good condition with light surface rust. Two ground cables were found and were secure. The access-way is in good condition and is fit for continued access. The PSV is in good condition. The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 510 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found the vessel to be in good condition. Internal surfaces are covered with light to moderate product scale. No corrosion or pitting was noted on any internal surfaces. All welds appear to be in good condition with no visible signs of defects. Nozzle and manway interiors were in good condition with light to moderate surface rusting. No signs of corrosion or erosion were noted within nozzle and manways. Old Anodes were replaced with new Anodes at time of inspection. Was not able to perform 100% visual inspection on Head 2 internal due to steel box welded to Head. Baffle plates and screens were in good condition and baffle welds to internal shell seem to be in good condition with no signs of defects. Approximately 1-2É?ù of sediment was covering the bottom. Removal of sediment in places revealed no corrosion or pitting.
UltraPipe Unit ID SEVERINI

V-401

Comments:
2015
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic thickness survey was performed on the floor. All readings have been entered into UltraPIPE and after a review of the data, the next inspection date will be 10/30/2035. The predicted retirement date of the floor is 10/30/2066 based on a 2 mil per year default corrosion rate. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness survey taken 10/30/2015. The next thickness survey will be time based at 20 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found the tank to be in good condition. One of the shell panels was removed to provide access for inspection and maintenance.
The floor was in good condition and the coating was intact. There were a few areas where the coating had chipped away and those areas had already been touched up prior to inspection.
The shell was in good condition and the coating was intact. Some nozzles have been added and the coating has been touched up in some areas. Nozzle additions appear to be consistent with API-12B design.
The roof was in good condition although an up-close inspection was not possible at this time due to lack of access. The underside of the roof appears to have no coating issues and no corrosion or rusting is visible. The roof supports are in good condition and do not show any signs of thinning or twisting. The center support post does not have alignment tabs to prevent movement.
There is a partition wall in the middle of the tank extending from the middle of course 1 to the middle of course 2. Additional supports were added for the partition during this maintenance window. The wall is in good condition and some of the supports are sitting on wood blocks while other supports are attached to the floor bolting. The anodes were replaced during this maintenance window.
Recommendations:
No recommendations at this time. The next internal inspection will be time based at 20 years.
2012
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell, nozzles & roof. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 06/13/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 09/22/2041 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
During this inspection, a hydro-test was being performed. External inspection found this tank is found to be in good condition. The external paint coating is in good condition. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall which is in good condition. Some crushed rock and new construction materials was found covering the chime, no soil buildup was found. Bottom leak detection soil sampling tubes are installed in the crushed rock bed foundation. A rope was used as a support on the fiber reinforced piping coming off the top of the tank. Several seams and nozzles with reinforcement were found leaking during the hydro-test. Maintenance will secure all bolting and gaskets to ensure no leaks will occur once the tank is placed into normal service. This tank was recently constructed and has not been placed in service. Oil debris was found from the vacuum breaker on the roof. Appears they used an existing vacuum breaker with oil residue still attached. The roof access accessway is securely attached to the tank and the paint coating is in fair condition with surface rusting present. Up-close inspection of the tank roof was not completed due to limited access. No excessive sagging was noted.
Recommendations: Excess hardware and light debris should be cleared out from the rock ring. Check bolting torque as necessary. Once the tank is placed into normal service, a re-inspection of the seams should be evaluated to ensure maintenance has securely tightened all loose bolts.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.
UltraPipe Unit ID PLAC
UltraPipe Circuit ID
TK-2A

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Inspection:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were completed in accordance with Applus RTD ‚Äì Valley Industrial
X-Ray established procedures. 15 thickness measurement locations (TMLs) were established and thickness measurements were taken at these locations.
All thickness readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection will be 05/29/2022 based on a 2 mil per year corrosion rate. The predicted retirement date of the circuit is 11/28/2068.
There are 0 caution TMLs per the current thickness reading taken on 05-29-2012.
API 570 Visual Inspection:
Visual inspection found this piping circuit to be in fair condition. The installation of this circuit was found incomplete at the well casing. The well will be reactivated utilizing new and old existing piping. Piping is in fair condition with surface rust around welds, heat affected zones, support shoes, bolting, and insulation interfaces. Some scale & C.U.I was found inside damaged areas of insulation. Insulation seals are failing and may require re-caulking & or possible re-insulating entire line due to the conditions of the insulation. External pitting was found approximately 0.005‚Äù-0.030‚Äù deep. In between CML 2 & 3 an arc strike was found on the east side of the pipe. No centralizers were found inside piping culverts. Support may be needed between CML 6 & 7. The pipe is slightly bowing downward at this location. Between CML 10 and the road crossing the insulated pipe goes under soil which appeared to have washed down the slope onto piping. The piping was inspected for code compliance issues and to identify possible leaks, stresses and any condition that might reduce the life of the piping circuit. All piping will be put on a maximum 10 year thickness inspection interval per API (class 3 piping) requirements. Some piping TML locations may require re-inspection prior to the maximum interval. See UltraPIPE data reports for all required inspection dates.
All piping will require an API 570 Visual inspection in 10 years.
UltraPipe Unit ID BELGIAN
UltraPipe Circuit ID WELL_33-23R_FL

API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank in good condition. The external paint coating is in good condition. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The retaining wall is in good condition over all except one area that has disconnected then re-connected using a bracket. No Soil buildup was found covering the chime. A vertical seam leak was leaking residue on the north side of the tank. Nozzle 30 and the 1É?ù sample line nearby had product leaking from the nozzle to tank connection. Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell, roof & nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 06/15/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is _________ based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 6/15/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank in fair condition. The paint coating is in fair condition and no external corrosion or pitting was found. Oil and soil buildup were found in the rock ring and the chime is partially covered with rock and soil in some locations. Several vertical seam leaks were noted possibly caused by loose bolting or failed gaskets. A 2É?ù nozzle on the west bottom side of the tank has some product leaking. Dimpling was found on the cleanout cover plate caused by a 6É?ù valve drain line that is inadequately supported. Oil stains were found around the thief hatch and emergency vent indicating that the tank may have been overfilled in the past. The roof access stairway is in good condition with no signs of corrosion or damage noted. The roof is in good condition with no excessive sagging or bulging noted. Some leaks were noted on the roof plates possibly indicating failed gaskets.
Recommendations: Excess oil residue and light debris should be cleared out from the rock ring and from the chime. Determine cause of roof and shell leaks and repair as necessary. Add a support to the 6É?ù drain off clean out cover plate. Service vents and thief hatch to ensure proper operation.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell, roof & nozzles.
All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 06/29/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 03/24/2027 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 6/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The shell insulation has distortion, punctures and is missing some areas in random locations including around most nozzles & no seals were found. Oil residue was found on the insulation jacketing in several places which could indicate possible shell seam leaks. Limited inspection of the shell was performed in areas where the insulation was missing. Surface rust and paint failure was found at these locations. No leaks were found on any nozzles exposed through insulation. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. The chime was completely covered in soil buildup and was not accessible for inspection. The access-way is secure to the tank and is found in fair condition with paint coating failure and surface rusting present. The roof is not coated and contains moderate surface rusting. Bolting was missing in several locations at the roof plate joints. Caulking or sealant was found at random locations on the roof joints. Gasket material is in poor condition on the roof.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
Recommendations:
Clean soil buildup from chime and re-inspect. Remove small sections of insulation in several areas to inspect for corrosion under insulation and check for leaks. Clean oil stains from insulation jacketing and monitor locations for leakage. If oil seepage returns, consider removing all insulation from the tank to identify the source of the leak and repair as necessary. Replace missing roof bolting and consider replacing roof plate gaskets.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.
UltraPipe Unit ID POSO
UltraPipe Circuit ID T-12

Comments:
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell and nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 11/06/2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 10/27/2030 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 11/06/2012.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in good condition. The external paint coating is in good condition. The tank foundation is a crushed rock ring with a steel retaining wall. This retaining wall is in good condition. Oil and soil buildup was found in the rock ring and on the chime. Two areas were found leaking product, 1É?ù sample threaded connection and a 10É?ù bolted cover plate to the tank. Near this 10É?ù cover plate the shell has slight warping approximately 1-2 feet from the bottom chime. This may have been cause by a possible overfill in the past. More evidence of the over fill can be seen from the gauge hatch and the vacuum breaker on the roof. These areas have product on and around them and appears to have run off the side of the roof onto the shell and accessway. Dimpling was found on the cleanout cover plate caused an unsupported 6É?ù drain line.
Recommendations: Determine cause of plate leaks and repair as necessary. Clean oil and soil buildups from the rock ring and restore the rock ring to a clean even fill. Remove soil buildup from the chime. Consider servicing the vents and thief hatch to ensure proper operation.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. Thorough cleaning was not completed prior to internal inspection; the shell 1st course had heavy product buildup and the floor had scattered puddles of product. Internal piping was covered in heavy product buildup. Areas cleaned were in good condition with no signs of coating failure or corrosion/pitting. No dimpling was noted around nozzles or in floor plates. The roof support structure was in good condition and shows no signs of degradation. All roof rafters are in place and show no signs of twisting, thinning or sagging. All visible bolts showed no signs of corrosion. Shell 2nd and 3rd courses and the roof.
Recommendations:
Clean all surfaces that have heavy product buildup and re-inspect.
UltraPipe Unit ID POSO
UltraPipe Circuit ID T-287

Comments:
?ˇ
Ultrasonic A-Scan Thickness Survey:
Ultrasonic A-Scan thickness measurements were performed on the shell, roof & nozzles. All readings have been entered into Ultra Pipe and after review of the data next inspection date will be 2017. The predicted retirement date of the tank is 04/27/2032 based on a 2 mil a year default corrosion rate. Retirement date is an average of the earliest 10% of all TML retirement dates for this equipment. There are 0 caution TML locations per the current thickness reading taken 6/27/2012. The next thickness survey will be time based at 5 years to establish a corrosion rate.
API 653 External Inspection:
External inspection found this tank to be in fair condition. The crushed rock foundation was found to have oil and soil completely covering the bottom angle area (chime).?ˇ The insulation is in fair condition with some product buildup on the west side of the tank.?ˇ No seals were found around the nozzles or manways.?ˇ Oil product was found leaking from the 20É?ù manway and the 2É?ù threaded piping off the 20É?ù manway. Oil product was also found on and around the sample hatch on the roof, on the south side of the roof from the overhead piping, and on the accessway stair case on the west side. Current site grading will not allow rainwater to flow away from the tank.
Recommendations: All crush rock and debris should be removed to inspect the bottom angle area (chime) and retaining wall. Add seals around nozzles and manways to prevent corrosion under insulation cause by water. Determine cause of leaks and repair as necessary. Grade site around tank to allow proper drainage away from tank. Clean oil and soil debris from rock ring and restore rock to even and clean fill to allow proper foundation drainage. Clean oil buildups from the roof and insulation and monitor areas for leaks.
The next external visual inspection will be time based at 5 years.
API 653 Internal Inspection:
Internal inspection was not scheduled at the time of this inspection. Internal inspection is recommended at the next planned shutdown.
